content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												A strong narrative and deeply branching story where your choices matter. You step into the role of a global peacekeeper in the near future, aboard a large future craft, inside which this story takes place.An on board murder has you looking for a killer on a ship with a NPC crew who work, socialize, go about their lives, react differently to your conversations and actions, as well as your response to unfolding events. It's some of the deepest conversation mechanics I've experienced, like a really fleshed out Mass Effect game taking place entirely on board one ship. It's probably the closest we will get to a block style RPG.There are some FP Shooter elements, namely hostiles and VR training, but the passive route can be taken with aggressors.A sequel has been funded on fig.co and I believe this entry will be ported over to UE4 in the future.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												An equivocal review of an intriguing game with one critical flaw.The characters of CONSORTIUM are each unique, supported by adequate-to-good voice acting, and they combine nicely with an interesting story to create a plausible and exciting environment. There is also an impressive amount of player agency within the small bounds of the scenario. The game's simple aesthetic mostly works well, though the bare animations do detract from immersion.Unfortunately the core experience of this game explicitly relies on save scumming (saving and loading to explore different gameplay options) and while saving is quick, the slow loading times are immersion-breaking when you try to follow the game's instruction to explore conversation trees. This is the main issue with the game as it stands: exploring the many complex branching conversations central to the game is changed from an exciting and fun experience into a slog.A few other, mostly minor, issues also detract from the game. Many conversations seem to just involve finding what to say to each character to increase their alignment- though many obvious exceptions make this a minor gripe and the game is still miles better than most other games in this regard. Combat is also limited, but functional, and given the scope and tone of the game the slight awkwardness may be appropriate. Finally, game-breaking bugs do exist but fortunately the developer seems to be active in supporting and fixing those as they are encountered.CONSORTIUM is pushing forward the boundaries of the art, and is certainly worthwhile. The game brings some intriguing ideas and a good story to the table, but sadly the load issue combined with other mechanical shortcomings were enough to push it slightly over the boundary to 'not-fun' for me. In my opinion it is worth supporting this game solely for the direction it is headed, but I would not recommend it to friends as a fun way to spend some time.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												If you are looking for something similar to System Shock... then don't look for it here ;). Which is not bad because this game is something new and something good.It's not a shooter game, it is not RPG-by-stats game. But it is truly roleplaying adventure game where you talk to others, solve criminal case by looking for clues and asking questions. There are shooting sections, there is inventory management but te core of the game is playing your role and expressing it by actions, inactions, words spoken and unspoken. Great experience that changes rules how NPC interactions can be implemented in the game.I played this game twice, and even though i tought i do everything the same i got different choices to pick just because i rushed some conversation straight to the point or didnt click one thing. You can play your style, you can break 4th wall, you can try playing role of character you play - short game with replay value and some achievements on the list makes me wonder 'how is that even possible? ive checked everything' :P.Dont be fooled by, maybe bad, screenshots - game looks really good when you play it and simplistic graphics serves it's purpose - you can clearly distinguish one NPC from another by simple features of face and haircut so when you are given task or clue to talk to somebody you can recognize them from afar.And even though game offers really limited space for your actions this space is used to its full extend. Scenery will change, rules will change, game will ofer new things within the same corridors.Story is solid and characters are well fleshed out. Some pieces of world lore or propaganda could be annoying as game obviously uses cliches, national stereotypes and puts real world politics or religious issues inside the game. Setting is parallel universes in future so why the game is full of nowadays topics? Feeling of being indoctrinated is so strong that everytime i see piece of this makes me roll my eyes and think 'omg, rly?'.As i wrote earlier - it is not a shooter game so shooting is really basic and quite simple. Enemies are just dolls to be shoot at and only difficulty is their endurance. You can't use covers and all focuses on taking enemy down without much tactics on how to do it - just keep their silhouettes within your crosshair and keep button pressed down.You can collect new gear, manage ammo and use energy to heal during battle but these features are not much used within this game.And why battle is in the game when there is not much action? Because it is just a first episode of upcoming action game where you enter the brawl in The Tower. It is like introductory sequence, shareware-alike kind of old games used to have where you had first episode to have fun and then you could buy full version. But for this one you have to pay full price in advance and episode will end up with a cliffhanger.Of course it is just information for the reader, not a flaw, i don't see a reason not to pay the devs for such a good piece of work. Game looks great, sounds great [full voiceover], is replayable and costs 10e. It is like going to the cinema but here you can change the outcome of the story if you like so :)

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												This game does many incredible things with its dynamic narrative and interactivity. There is nothing quite like it, and I recommend being as little prepared as possible for what you're getting into. It wields a brand of tension, intrigue, and even horror like no other game out there.However, I will say that I found the Shooter elements to be exceptionally lacking. The bright side is that all violence is completely avoidable. Someday I'll brave the combat mechanics in order to experience some of the other story branches, but you can easily get your money's worth without doing so.Er, I'm sorry. Did I say this was a game? Don't let the simulation's low fidelity fool you: these are real people. You may be immune to the consequences of your choices, but the people you meet will not be so fortunate. Act accordingly. Or don't, you monster.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Consortium is a RPG unlike any others. The best way I can put this game into perspective is to think of the Mass effect series games, reduces its scope to just one setting but focus entirely on dialogues choices and characters interaction.  The setting you are playing on, a huge command plane similar to the BUS in Agents of SHIELD, is full of interesting characters, of which all of them are voiced over. The people you encountered are all believable; each has interesting thing to say either about themselves, their colleagues and the world around them. Conservations seem life-like as the choices are timed so you can’t be holding on to decide what to say next, and “say nothing” is always present for all dialogue options. You can even walk away during a conversation and the characters would react to it. Talking to them is a lot of fun; the dialogues are entertaining as well as giving background story about the world. There’s even a part which your answer is breaking the fourth wall, and at first it seem like a joke response to one of the character inquiry but to my surprise, later on the game the character actually referred back to your response and if you persist  enough will become one of the subplot. Now the story, essentially you are trying to solve a murder happened shortly while you are on board but as the story unfold it hinted on a larger mystery / conspiracy hangs in the shadow.  The story is engaging but slow at the beginning, it picked up pace around the middle but ended in a cliff hanger. I would say that’s the only negative thing about the game. Combat is simple and basic but it is not irrelevant. It does feel dated as it is still using the source engine.  With that said combat has a choice of lethal and non-lethal and a fairly basic inventory system. But seeing that you can actually complete the game without firing a single shot, there is definitely less emphasis on combat.All in all I would definitely recommend this game as it mixed rpg, adventure game, and FPS into something that is quite unique.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												This is a very strange game. Your first clue is that it claims to be real. The deal is, you used a system by iDGi to take control of Bishop-6, a general-operations crewmember aboard the Zenlilth in the year 2043. The Zenlilth is a highly advanced plane containing a chess-based heirarchy, all working for the leaders of Consortium, King and Queen. Your purpose is to do stuff, and try not to screw up the plane too badly through traitors, mercenary attacks, and intrigue. There's even a section where the high leader of Consortium calls you specifically to tell you not to kill the guy you're controlling. It is, in my opinion, well-written and creative, and if Bioware RPG's are too busy for you, this is much more story-focused and less shooting and picking flowers.The combat is unique, and takes backstage. As a "Bishop", you are supposed to know how to fight, but in the only big combat scene of the game people get a bit annoyed if you kill too many people (especially the leader). Story is unique and immersive, the ending is incredibly strange and yet not out of place. So much detail is put into a facade of reality that the same section of a game might be experienced with bad space/time continuum connection the first time, and some static the next. There's a lot more to learn and I've played through the game twice. Is it worth 20$? Maybe. Is it worth the money you pay when on sale for 33% off or more? Definitely.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Today, I’m talking about a little first-person action-adventure game called CONSORTIUM. Developed and self-published by Interdimensional Games, Inc. The games development had its start in a successful Kickstarter campaign, which leads us to what we have today. CONSORTIUM’s story starts off with you, the player, travelling forward through time, and to a parallel universe, thanks to a satellite that allows us to connect to a sentient A.I. that exists in the other universe. In this future universe, it seems that everything is just about perfect. Global hunger, energy, and poverty problems has been resolved for the most part, and all forms of war have almost completely ceased. We have people living in space, on the moon, on Mars, you name it. But can things ever really be perfect?Consortium1You take the role of someone named Bishop Six, a field agent and peacekeeper of sorts in the Consortium, a society dedicated to protecting the galaxy or something. But all is not well, as soon after you arrive on your ship, the Zenlil, one of your shipmates is found dead in their bunkroom. Believing them to have been murdered by another shipmate, you are commanded to begin interrogating your shipmates to find out who the traitor is. If that weren’t enough, you also have the problem of a band of outlaws currently looking to take down your ship. It’s up to you to solve the mystery behind the murder, and take down the outlaws, among other things. But you better watch out, nobody can know where you’re really from, otherwise you might end up causing a temporal breakdown and destroy the universe!So, let me tell you right now: Gameplay is where this game really shines. CONSORTIUM really isn’t an action game, so much as it is an immersive story told through its great character dialogue, its mysteries, and the in-game lore that comes with it. You communicate to the other characters on the ship through simple button presses, similar to a Telltale game. Alternatively, you can choose to say nothing and make everything awkward with your constant silence. Like I said before, one of the major goals is trying to find out who the murderer on your ship is, but naturally, things can never just be that simple. News gets spread fast on Zenlil, and before you know it, everybody on the ship knows what has happened, which naturally freaks them out. As you question and get to know your shipmates, you find that quite a few of them are less trustworthy than they appear, and others seem way too nervous or in some cases, optimistic about the whole situation. But, for those of you out there who decide that there isn’t enough shooting involved, there ARE action segments included with the game. Depending on how you choose to interact with other characters, you will be forced to engage in combat with bloodthirsty mercenaries who invade your ship, or shoot down enemy spaceships. You are also given the choice of capturing, or outright killing their leader. Just remember: Gameplay, as well as the story itself, might turn out differently depending on what you’ve chosen to do or not do.Consortium3Everything looks decent in terms of graphics, but the game was built on the constantly aging Source Engine, so you probably shouldn’t expect anything too fancy. Because it IS Source though, you can be almost certain that CONSORTIUM will run on even the lowest-end of gaming PCs. The sound effects are pretty good too, really helping encapsulate that claustrophobic feeling of being on a small little spaceship. The music is absolutely fantastic, but what do you expect when it’s composed by none other than Jeremy Soule, the same guy who did the music for such great games as Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, and Knights of the Old Republic? The developers really use the music to their advantage here when it comes to telling the story, and really puts an emphasis on the importance of what’s going on around you.If there was one major flaw I could point out about this game, it’s that it was too short for my tastes. If you want a short, but good little immersive plot-central game, I recommend you try out CONSORTIUM. It’s currently on sale on Steam for $19.99.http://wtbfun.com/consortium-review/

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												A video game that's not really comparable to other video games, because there really isn't anything like it. I've played through it once already and just started a second playthrough, and I think I'll continue playing it beyond that. No point in explaining what the game is (just read the store page), but I will say that they ♥♥♥♥ing nailed it. Starting off with the writing, I was blown away. The lore is insanely extensive, which you can find by just playing the game or accessing the terminal on the ship or reading the "iDGi-1 Discoveries" compedium (included with the game for free). It's rare to see a game take its lore as seriously as this one does. The actual writing in the game's story is great as well, with characters having their own distinct personalities (as they should) - and the way you interact with (or don't) with these characters actually has an impact on the way they treat you and even the outcome of the story. The branching paths of the story not only make replayability possible, but they seem designed around taking advantage of replayability (and replaying actually fits the lore!) - a good comparison (apparently) is Undertale.Gameplay-wise, the game is mostly talking to people. There are a few combat scenarios, one being in a virtual world, but for the most part you won't do much shooting. The combat itself can be approached in multiple ways, offering lethal, non-lethal, or a little of both. This also has a noticeable impact on the game and its world. The actual combat mechanics aren't anything amazing and are rarely used, so you probably shouldn't waste what little inventory space you have trying to carry an entire armory.Now the complaints! At times, the voice acting was particularly hammy - sometimes even outright bad. Most of the time it was just decent. Visually, the game was a headache - at least at first. I can appreciate an art style but the shadows and lighting just seemed to detract from everything, and it just felt like they were progressing backwards in their art direction. The UI is especially messy, and the main menu is an eyesore. I feel like this could be attributed to the engine, as Source is and was pretty severely dated at the time of this game's release. At least the sequel seems to be rectifying that.To quickly address the length, it is short. I can see how some might think 3-5 hours is petty for a $15 game, but with the amount of replayability and the fact that replaying actually changes things, I'm alright with that price. Is it worth the money? Absolutely. I'm actually ashamed I got this for free, and would have gladly paid for it had I known it was this good (though I did back the sequel on Kickstarter, as should you if you're reading this within 24 days of posting).

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												One of the best and most unique games I've played in a while. A genius scifi-rpg from FPS perspective, taking place entirely on a plane. Murder mystery and much more.Pros:- Strong, captivating story, some great characters and plot twists- Short to play through once, but excellent replay value. The main mystery can only be pieced together after multiple walkthroughs, and it's really worth exploring different paths (some by reloads, some by new universes).- Great dialogs and voice acting, with the option to say nothing or just walk away from any conversation- Unique and sometimes disturbing meta-game aspect. You don't play the character in the game, you play yourself controlling the character, which allows for weird effects, smart use of glitches and limitations, and can even be discovered by characters you encounter...- Deep and interesting game lore + an info database you can search for any keyword and discover new stuff- Excellent soundtrack by Jeremy SouleCons:- Not beautiful (though going well with the art style), Source engine is not well suited for the confined space- Slow (re)loading times (I read this is because of Source)- UI could use some improvement (I love the design but some functionality could be better)- Combat and inventory management are overly complicated and unrewarding. Luckily they have little role in the game- (for me at least) a bit hard to keep track of all the NPCs relations- somewhat anticlimatic cliffhanger ending leading to the planned sequel

You will have a great time in this game.Get it!(No, it is NOT open world, it is NOT a shooter, it is NOT a point and click adventure and NO, there is NO multiplayer, go away)

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												I really tried to like this game. I really did. It just never clicked. Pros voice acting on all characters fairly intuitive controls diverse personality rostercons mission objectives sometimes hard to understand personality roster is odd bad timings in conversationsThings can happen at the same time. You can have a long discussion with a character and someone else will talk to you at the same time, making everything confusing.Characters talk to you like they know you and don't know you at the same time. You're a new guy there which...makes sense I guess?Locations are odd. Sometimes you're told to do something, but you have no clear as to what the person is talking about or what the thing you're supposed to look for looks like.Then there's the whole mind transfer thing. You're thrown into another person's body after a creepy cutscene with nearly no explanation as to why. The only thing this does is to impose annoying static. I'm sure there's a point, but I never got to that. The game tries to do a lot of things at the same time.There are a lot of options/storylines going on at the same time, which, if you're a perfectionist and you don't mind going through every detail more than once will make this a gift to you. I don't mind sleuthing, but the level this game takes it to is just a notch over what I find to be pleasant.The traitor quest was damn near impossible too.Needless to say I never made it farther than to the discussion with the Queen. Took a few wrong turns and disconnected.I feel that this could've been a really good game, but something went wrong in the process.PS: the game is 6 Gigs and I have no idea why.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												This is like the first 15 minutes of a movie. If you like real time unskippable cut scenes, you'll love this. There's a lot of gushing over this being dynamic or choices with consquences, but that's significantly overstated.The game developers packed a crap ton of text into the onboard computers, so... if you want you can read over twenty five six page articles about something about the setting this is suppose to take place in. The story takes place on a fairly claustrophobic cartoon ship and the combat mechanic is weak. The story is kinda meta and references you playing a game, but as like a serious acknowledgement woven into the story rather than tonge in cheek. There's a lame murder mystery thing, confused only by the fact all the characters have identical titles with a number and look pretty much the same too. The definitive "clue" makes no sense in the context of a saboteur committing murder. Contrived mystery is really central to what little there is here, so it shouldn't be a spoiler to say that aspect falls flat. Rest of the game is go from one cut scene to another cut scene. Sometimes you can walk away in the middle of a conversation, sometimes the door inexplicably locks behind you.  After sitting through an eye rolling mission briefing about Osama Bin Laden's son taking a building hostage, you paratrooper from the plane and the game ends before it starts.It probably would be an alright tutorial or intro to a game, but this probably shouldn't have been released as if it was a real game. I can't in good conscious recommend this to a general audience. Go play the Stanley Parable if you want an unconventional narrative and an exploration into player choice.

number of helpful: 57 of 111 people (51%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												It took me a bit to determine if I would recommend this game and the answer has to be no. In the end, the actual "game" is extremely lacking and the best bits really leave you wanting more. It might have a great sequel, but as it is, I can't recommend it.The bad stuff. So there isn't really a game here. There are the concepts of a FPS intermixed and there are even a couple VR training sessions that show off a functional shooter. It's not great, but it's functional. Oh and there's a bug where apparently the AI cannot figure out where you are if you go up two ramps from the starting level.In the game itself, there are at most two parts that can involve combat. If you play "correctly," there will be no combat though. If you don't, it's again not very good combat.So the experience rests firmly on the story and the interactions. The actual writing of all of the lines is pretty good overall with respectable voice acting. There just isn't any real motivating force past either advancing the game or I don't have anything better to do to actually play along. There is a ton of information you clearly are left out of, but the game never really lets you into that. Maybe with some more context or something, I would care, but as presented, I just don't.So that sounds like all of the game. Why would this be hard for me to say yes or no to the recommend to it? It sounds boring to bad overall.There are glimmers of something great in here. The meta story could be actually pretty interesting. I would love for there to be more to it. At the end, it even seemed to be coming through a bit.There actually seem to be characters in this game. People have glimmers of personalities and conflicts. That all seems great. No one happens to develop anywhere near enough for me to care about them, but I can see things there.The entire game takes place on one (large) plane. I love that in such a condensed space, you can have quite a few interactions and it felt decently real (as in a reasonable series of events). Hell, even the plane felt appropriate where there were places for people to sleep and relax and eat and such while remaining very tight and small. Unfortunately those interactions all end up being boring.So I really want to see what comes of the sequel which I believe starts kickstarting soon. This isn't the game I wanted to play, but it is a world I'm interesting in revisiting.

												Interesting take on non-linear adventure game combined with murder-room mystery elements. I didn't expect it but it was really fun talking with all the crew and finding out whodunit. I really liked the freedom of choice in dialogues and compelling branching strory set in interesting future world.Sometimes it was very hard to differentiate between all those numbered chess-like nicknames as whole hiearachy definitely needs some time to get used to (I would appreciate showing normal names anytime). Browsing through main terminal was mainly boring because most of the texts were written as interviews with too much beating around the bush (I would prefer shorter news-like summaries). But overall it is surprising hidden gem. and I'm glad I found it.I recommend this game to anyone who prefers talking their way out instead of fighting in other RPGs.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												CONSORTIUM is absolutely fantastic.It's very like one of those well loved but sort of clunky RPGs, like Deus Ex, Vampire: The Masquerade Bloodlines or EYE: Divine Cybermancy. If you can look beyond the flaws, which I personally haven't really suffered, it's a fantastic game. I've only played around 3 hours (so Steam tells me) but I could swear it's been more. It's absolutely astounding, the visuals are interesting, and the world is so rich! There's a computer bank with literally thousands of ebooks in detailing the world. There's so much there I really can't even begin to absorb it. It's got a real diversity in playstyle, too. For example, the big bad of the first act, I looked him up, worked out a bit about his personality, and when speaking to him, played his ego and curiosity. This meant I could defeat him and his army, then his fleet without firing a single bullet or hurting anyone.Alternatively, I attempted a more violent approach, but I personally never found that to be the best way. The richness with the way you interact and chat with the characters makes you genuinely develop emotion towards them, not forced emotion, such as in The Walking Dead. They each have their own metric ton of things to say, and your behaviour changes their thoughts towards you, and the same will go for you.The setting is very rich, like a Gerry Anderson serial, or something. I was strongly reminded of Spectrum, with the whole codename system and flying base. The only sort of problem with this is that nearly every character is designated as Pawn and then a number. This means I got very confused when investigating an incident that comes out through the game. I actually ended up screwing my alignment utterly with two characters and failing to find the bad guy. This did sort of annoy me, but the game does tell you that regular saves are a good idea, and I decided to not do that to add a more permanent level to my choices.I can imagine that there's so many ways to approach this game, so I can't comment on the scope of it. It can also be very tense in some parts, like when you're being interrogated about your name and stuff.All in all, this is one of those games you will love if you can focus past things like attempting the usual tutorial and introduction dialouges with NPCs being met with "Are you feeling okay? You've forgotten everything" and other things. The developers have also promised to fix the bugs that have damaged some people's experience, too.

												Someone called Consortium an interactive StarTrek episode, and boy was he/she right!This title is a mix of roleplay, shooter (not much, but still) and advemture game, strongly depending on bulding relationship with crew members (or making them hate your character, if you like) which will be the key to solve the mystery taking place on Zenlil. Simulator of your alter ego who will have a big impact on the other world. Literally and figuratively.The first playtrough took me 15 hours, but I'm an explorer who wants to find as much as he can for the first time. I took my time for doing the detective work (reading logs, speaking with npc etc) so surely my timeplay will stand aside from the typical 5-6h people have. Still, hours very good spended.I hope the game will have more attention from the press and that people will help fund the second episode. This title has a great potential to become next years Deus Ex.

Posted: February 2, 2016
												It's a very strange game. And I'm talking about the plot as much as the game itself. First off, it looks absolutely terrible, but if you can get over that it looks like it was made by a bunch of amateurs, it's actually kind of interesting.It's more or less a walking and talking simulator on a space ship. You interact with the crew in first-person navigating through dialogue trees to solve various mysteries that your crew runs in to. Things happen in real-time as well, so you can actually miss some clues if you weren't at a certain place at a certain time. Voice acting isn't bad and the music was created by Jeremy Soule, so it's actually quite an enjoyable experience the first time around.Ends in an awful cliffhanger, but you can at least solve the one big mystery. I got it for free, but I don't know if it's something I'd pay $15 for.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												CONSORTIUM is a heavily story based and very conceptual game. It has this slight feeling of leaning towards AAA games, but instead of being a few hour long rollercoaster ride with splosions and lols, it focuses more on ideas while providing more gamplay than usual indie titles.Story is the main point in the game, but it has so many branches that it would require a dozen playthroughs to get them all.  In one conversation you can change the whole outcome of the game, then in the next one, you might change it all again, everything depends on your choice. You can be a modest doing-my-job guy or a cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or a complete weirdo. And again, this may or may not impact the outcome. Honestly before this game I did not think you can make so many changes in story with  2-5 dialogue choices.While the game has combat which is moderate (and that's what makes the game lean towards AAA FPS rather than being full chit-chat indie title), it can completely avoided through dialogue OR you can turn the game into a bloodbath. Graphics aren't impresive but bearable (though somewhat unusual, thus giving some originality to the game), same about sounds.CONSORTIUM combines FPS, RPG and mystery solving while being heavily story driven, and makes me wish more AAA titles would adopt such ways of story telling. Not just 2-3 outcomes and call it best game ever with multiple endings, but story that changes with every choice you make.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I budgeted a whole two hours for games when I picked this up and I spent like... four on it before I knew what had happened.It's a little rough around the 'indie' edges, but the conversation tree/affection-rating systems clashing with your goals of playing detective, diplomat, and warrior? All good fun. All while trying to figure out what's going on with the metagame without letting slip that you're actually a remote-control operator from the past in 2013.The 4th-wall-breaking conceit behind the game is that the entire game is apparently a VR simulator delivered to you at your PC via uplink to a satellite which is making use of tachyon bursts or some♥♥♥♥♥♥to transmit temporally-adjusted data with an advanced, benevolent AI in the future, allowing you to remote-control an specific, nominated avatar at a fixed point in the future, generating a number of 'branched' alternate realities - based on your decisions - which the AI can track via other satellites in other parallel universes, spreading itself as a single entity functioning on nodes across all of them.The rest of the story is best kept a mystery because it's kind of fun getting clues from the crew about the world lore and politics etc, without asking the standard, "Duh, so what is the deal with [Major Faction even a child should know about]?" RPG questions. Those options are still there but the crew will think you're a bit dozy or incompetent because of it, and start to regard you suspiciously or with hostility.There's an in-game encyclopedia, but it seems like it only decelerates time to a certain degree to allow you to catch up, meaning that significant events and conversation opportunities can pass by or run their course without you. A veteran can probably see where most of the threads are underlying all this, and manipulate things appropriately, but if you let the smoke and mirrors do their job, I'd say this one's a fun one to get into.The mechanics of combat and the rest are not the smoothest, occasionally fiddly and unintuitive, but you can avoid most twitch-dependency if you're so inclined, through game-choices. It's definitely more substance than style, with some kind of dated graphics.  Either way, none of this got in the way for me, so I can pretty confidently give this an overall thumbs up.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												It looked so promising, but I was disappointed. CONSORTIUM is a game that holds itself together with its plot, but that's where it suffered.To truly appreciate everything the developers are trying to do, you need to read reems and reems of backstory prose, delve into blogs, read "musings", and even play another game by the same developers. The combat is pretty terrible - it could have been removed or simplified without any real impact to the game. You're constantly thrust into weird scenarios in which everyone else seems to know something you don't. There is a *lot* of talking. Yes, the plot is very important, but sometimes you're going to feel more like a passenger than a driver.The concept of the game itself being a gateway into an alternate reality broke my immersion more than anything else. The fourth wall was broken and never ended up being repaired. I soon stopped caring about the characters, the ship, or the mission. The setting just didn't have a good draw. The technology is advanced, and there are some interesting concepts in there, but the game might have been more interesting with more simplification.Set it on an orbiting spaceship instead of an aeroplane; provide a concise glossary or encylclopaedia; cut down the number of weapons to just one (you don't need a lethal assault rifle with a stun-grenade launcher attachment *and* a stun gun with a lethal laser mode); and most of all - utilise SHOW instead of TELL as a storytelling/exposition tool.I read all of the database entries in Mass Effect because they enhanced my experience, but in CONSORTIUM the extra information is pretty much mandatory reading if you want to understand what's going on - and the entries are *really* long. Let me put it this way: I can tell you all about the First Contact War and how the Mass Relays work in Mass Effect, but I'm still not sure I know what the Consortium itself actually is, what its ideals are, or how it does what it's supposed to be doing.Conversing with the crew and interacting with them is really important, but if you miss one or two key lines, you can miss a heck of a lot of content (and it really hurts your chances of solving the main mystery).If you get excited over the idea of a computer game pretending to be a door into another dimension where you can tell people "I'm from another world, playing a computer game, and you're all characters in that computer game. If I load a saved game, I'm breaking the timeline and creating another alternate reality..." then maybe you'll enjoy CONSORTIUM, but for me it was laid on a bit too thick.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Consortium is able to be a game world that is realized on a scale that is able to immerse the player wholly. Now, getting off the Webster-Merriam high horse, Consortium is able to deliver a world that feels real and right. This is a believable world with as much character as any world should have if it is to be as much a character as any other. It does not wait for you to give it the green light to move forward. The universe will continue on whether you're ready or not. The cast of this game, as well, truly feels alive and they interact realistically. When you're not watching, they still have full agendas, talking with people and moving around, doing their jobs. When you talk to them, they are able to feel fleshed out and they react realistically as if you have existed in this world. In a nutshell, this game is a must-play for those who love story and conversation as well as being able to immerse themselves for a few hours in a soon to be continued game world.

												This game is NOT designed to be played only once. There are many things that you can only unlock or discover if you play several times, knowing what will happen and when. The game is designed like that. Play it at least twice, changing your behavior, visiting different parts of the ship at different times, doing differently every time. You'll then find that this game is NOT short, but it's engaging nonetheless (you won't get bored after the first pass, far from it).The biggest "miss" IMO are the huge information documents that describe the lore, the setting, and several key points of the plot. Overly descriptive, boring, and excessively "not-to-the-point".

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Awesome game I almost missed out on because the first load took ages and was ready to quit when it finished.The plot, setting, and characters are excellent. You're a traveller to a parallel universe's Earth where you play as a Bishop (lorewise, something between secret agent and one man army) on his first day on duty, aboard a plane called the Zenlil. From the start, you will be exploring highly branching conversation options with many of the crew's members. The only thing I had heard about the gameplay before going in was that "everything you do has a consequence", and I found that to be largely true.The somewhat limited duration of the narration means you don't get to know all of the characters in depth; the lower-ranking servicemen in particular can be one-dimensional. For those you do get to know, you learn enough of to really want to see how they'd react to future situations as well. The voice acting is solid throughout.Everything in the graphics department feels source engine-ish. On the bright side, even as a player who will sometimes not play certain games solely because of the graphics, they didn't bother me too much. They got the job done well enough, and there was enough detail put in that they weren't bland.The combat is clunky at best, and is by far the game's weakest point, but its presence does help with the setting, which was lovingly crafted (in that it'd be harder to believe your tough enforcer background without the combat scenes to prove you're as good as they say you are/should be). Also, there's a news article database where you can read articles on the world's lore, many of them simply there for the curious.Overall, this was a very pleasant experience for me. I'd say it's a must-play for anyone looking for a great narrative delivered in a fresh way.

												If I had to describe this game in a phrase, I'd say "kinda like Star Trek on a high-tech jet with Mass Effect dialog options minus persuasion stats." I could blab about what everyone else has already said, but I'll just say "ditto" to what the positive reviews are in agreement about. It's a fun experience. If you are wanting a first person shooter, I can promise you this game will not deliver on that front. You play in first person and there are a couple of parts where you may shoot, but they're pretty weak and not very good. I kinda feel like the game doesn't actually need any first person (or third) shooting at all, but I suppose that might be for the sake of empowerment and a bit of realism. Long story short, the shooting sucks, but that's almost non-existent in the game. I feel like I'm making the game sound bad, but I really liked it and will buy the sequel at launch, if/whenever that might be. The story is great and there seem to be a lot of different options and ways some events can play out. Good stuff!Take note that almost every negative review is about game-stopping bugs that supposedly no longer exist. I didn't encounter any myself now that version 1.2 is out. So think about that when considering those reviews! =)

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												This game may not look like much to start... but it captures "role playing" in a way that I seldom see done well enough. Your conversations feel a little more real and emersive, and the choices you can make can quickly turn a shakey relationship sour, causing not just that character, but others to react differently in entirety, not just a small quip or comment made at somepoint, highlighting your choice for 5 seconds of "ah ha!" and then fading into obsurity like nothing really mattered in the end. The characters you interact with all have unique personalities and react like people, not exposition-spouting info logs at your disposal. In the end, I was satisfied with it. It held my interest, made me think, and didn't make me feel like I was being held by the hand and led through a tour. It was an experiece I really enjoyed.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												To start:  I love this game.  But, it can be little rough at the moment.I was a backer on this game during Kickstarter, I was very intrigued at the setting, art style, and gameplay premise.  It seemed to be a unique take and full of great new ideas.  In this respect the game did not dissapoint me.  The weighted crew interactions are very well done and I found the voice work to be pretty good.  The first core gameplay centers around conversations with crew members of the Zenlil, navigating dialog trees to increase or decrease approval with different crew members and opening up new lines of inquiry and knowledge.  The second is exploring the Zenlil craft and interacting with it, though in this game it is a bit limited by what the scripting allows.  Third is the FPS combat, and in my particular playthrough it took a backseat, though depending in your actions you could get a lot more.The story and plot started off well and became more and more intrigueing as the game progressed.  It takes place in the future, where your psyche has taken possession of a soldier on the combat aircraft Zenlil of the international Consortium.  Your mind has been sent forward to this realm through a special satellite system presented as a game.  But is it really a game?  What are the true motives of those who control the system?  And what might happen if you try to test the limits of that control?  Play to find out.The world of Consortium is surprisingly deep, and there is an in-game knowledge center for those who really like to dig into the lore.  Multiple in-game hints also indicated that there is an ARG that links to the world that provides more background.  By the end I found myself with a few "Oh Wow" moments that really have me looking forward to the second Consortium game. Now for a few negatives.  Despite the tremendous quality of the game from a small indie developer, the many branching pathways and moving parts are pretty complex, and I ran into quite a few bugs right off the bat.  I began playing with the Humble Bundle download version, and it seemed to have several issues with NPC pathing, especially getting stuck in doorways, blocking access and forcing me to start over.  I also ran into situations where the scripting would get out of sync and I would, for example, get caught in a loop where I ended a conversation and then the airplane exploded, only the reload at the last save and explode again.  The solution?  Save, save, save.  Once I got into the old school habit of making an incremental save between different encounters, I was able to work around various issues and continue playing.When I got my key and changed to the Steam version, I noted it seemed to work better and several bugs present in the Humble version were not present.Overall I am extremely pleased with my decision to back these fine folks on Kickstarter and have greatly enjoyed the game.  Those who are not patient enough to deal with progress halting bugs should avoid for now, and await patches which are swiftly being worked on.  The setting is incredibly rich and begs to be expanded in future titles, which I eagerly await.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Consortium is the big boy alternative to the walking simulator.The first thing that is apparent once you start this game is the degree of bone-crushing depth to the world the developers have created. There are dozens of pages of lore contextualizing every character in the plot, every event in the meta-narrative, and the vision of the future created for this game. This is exactly what people of a certain old school demographic in gaming claim to want in an RPG, but it is instead built upon a mediocre Half Life-esque shooter's skeleton.I say that, but there is more than one path to progress through the game in which the player doesn't need to engage in combat at all. In fact, Consortium places gunplay in the back seat, leaving the plot to be the driving force. The more active gameplay is, however, still in the car, unlike other "games" lauded for their plot but devoid of anything but the simplest interactivity. There is challenge to the combat, sometimes born of the situations, sometimes born of the tight spaces of the ship or the sheer number of enemies players are expected to deal with in one fight. There are also minigames, most notably a Missle Command-esque game that, while not difficult, is engaging enough. The point is, Consortium, while focused on story, does not shun gameplay, or even the fact that it is a game. There are even dialogue options for players who wish there to be no 4th Wall at all.And the subject of dialogue options brings me to the final point in this game's favour: The degree to which the player shapes the story. Consortium is near the level of Obsidian's Alpha Protocol in terms of the permutations each event can have, and each conversation, no matter how trivial, has at least two different potential statements a player can make. This helps immensely in helping the player engage with the rest of the cast, who are all distinct in personality, and for the most part well acted, even if some performances are clearly better than others.As I said, Consortium is a big boy alternative to the walking simulator; games that use a focus on story as an excuse to be little more than a film with a few QTEs or childishly easy puzzles. It has RPG-level depth at FPS prices and is not ashamed to go into the absolute minutia about the world it seeks to build for future sequels. If those sequels stay true to this game while improving the more combat-oriented approaches, they would deserve consideration alongside the greats in the Science Fiction genre of video games.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												This kind of felt like a High Concept game. Other than a few bugs, I found my first playthrough to be very enjoyable. The story and choices were fun aspects. The universe and technology was really interesting. The theme, while initially was a little challenging to follow, turned out to be very facinating. By the time the game was done, I was begging for more. And that's actually where the problem comes in.The game invites you to play it over-and-over, but I couldn't. But the game length wasn't long enough to justify it another play through. Even despite the different narrative choices and the mechancal aspects that intertwine the changing story and gameplay, the overarching story will be the same. And it just feels too samey with the other playthroughs.When the game ended, I was disappointed. It felt like I just finished the very entertaining and scene setting prolog, and it was game over.Other criticisms include the fourth wall being broken; that just never seems to quite work. I want to get immersed in an RPG-like game, I don't want it to point out "Hey. You're playing a video game!" - Let me be a part of this beautiful world. I fullly grasp the attempt at the metaplot. But it just didn't work for me.There's so much potential in this game.Ultimately, Consortium creates a beautiful setting, with smart game mechinisms. I would absolutely recommend people play it. But due to short narrative, unsatisifying cliff-hanger, and a few other minor things, I would only suggest picking it up when it is on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												CONSORTIUM is an odd beast. I can honestly say I had a great time with it, and can tell that the developers put a lot of time, effort, and heart into getting this indie creation to function like it does. I'd compare it favorably to the sections in MASS EFFECT where you just chat it up with your crew on the Normandy, learn a little bit about every one, affect their lives in little ways.In CONSORTIUM, the crew is a lot less diverse (sometimes, I had trouble telling them apart), but the reactivity is absolutely fantastic. Going through the achievements, I can see so many different outcomes to choices that I made half-heartedly at the time. There's a lot of opportunity for replayablilty here. That is if you're on-board with the game's premise of spending 4-5ish hours getting to know its cast of characters in a confined flying command center.If you love the dialog/choice-heavy sections of modern RPGs, here's a great little game that's built entirely around that. As someone who always puts points into charisma in RPGs (I know, I know), CONSORTIUM was right up my alley.It's definitely not perfect. There are entire systems (inventory and ammo management) built around its very clunky combat mechanics, but I can only think of a few times when you have occasion to use your gun. You'll probably see more combat in the combat training scenario than in the rest of the game combined. It gives the impression of a game that's trying to "check a box" rather than make it a key part of the experience. It is a-okay to not have combat in a game like this. When CONSORTIUM was at its best, it reminded me of TITANIC: ADVENTURE OUT OF TIME. No combat, intriguing story, interesting characters, worthwhile investigation sections. An all-around great game.There was also a bit of story-bending to an ARG that I didn't know existed, but apparently does. In the moment, I felt a little lost, like there was a crucial part of the story I was missing.Overall, really enjoyed my experience. Confined and relatively brief, though it was, the game is also very dense. I can easily see myself playing through this a couple more times to see different outcomes. Eager to see how Part II of the trilogy eventually plays out!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Pros:+ Excellent voice acting+ Fairly interesting lore and meta story+ Simple but effective dialogue system+ Potential for completely branching story+ Warrants multiple playthroughs+ Nice sci-fi setting+ Decent graphicsCons:- Combat is so-so (though it can be completely avoided in the main story depending on your actions)- No map system (quite difficult to navigate if you haven't completely memorized the ship's layout)- Can potentially only be an hour or so's entertainment- Long loading times- Some bugs/glitches (though none game-breaking from what I've seen)CONSORTIUM is a strange little experiment which is surprisingly enjoyable. Although I consider it a hidden gem, there are definitely plenty of things that may put other people off. If you're looking for combat, look somewhere else. However, if you're looking for a short-ish experience with some decent atmosphere, characters and story, I'd say this is worth a look. I got the game for free as part of a free weekend, and I've seen it discounted as low as £2, so I would recommend getting it on sale, as the £6.99 asking price feels a little steep. Also bear in mind that if you're one for satisfying endings, this will most likely disappoint you. The ending is a cliffhanger, leaves lots of unanswered questions, and encourages you to buy the sequel; CONSORTIUM: THE TOWER (which is currently being crowdfunded (the devs have also stated that if it does not meet its target funding then the sequel will be put on hold indefinitely)) when it comes out. At a discounted price, and especially if it's free, CONSORTIUM is well worth your time.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												To me personally this was an incredibly interesting game. It completely subverted my expectations about it when I started playing it. I am so used to getting into a game, listening to 10-15 min of expostition and story content that isn't developed or focused on again until the end, that when I went past that point with CONSORTIUM I was slightly taken aback and realized that this truly is a story focused RPG. And best of all it managed to hold my attention to the story throughout the whole game, and only games with great stories have managed that (sadly, there aren't too many of those). Perhaps this is only a side effect of the fact the game is unexpectedly short, even the story itself doesn't have a good conclusion. It is very much dependant on a sequel, however it is not yet clear if we are going to get one.The game also has an FPS element to it, which is very much underdeveloped. You have an inventory and equipment system, which you manage throughout the game, so that you will be optimally prepared for combat when the need arises for it. But sadly, that moment doesn't ever come. Not really that is, there are two seperate instances in the game where you can use weapons, in the first one it is clear that the game is pushing you towards the non-violent path. The second one is a bit more mandatory, however you can win that fight simply by waiting it out...CONSORTIUM reminded me of the times when you are aboard the Normandy in the Mass Effect games and you go around talking to your crewmembers, getting to know them and their story and actually progressing the overall story somewhat. I enjoyed that part in the Mass Effect games, it made me connect with the characters. This game only has that part, but it does it so much better. It would appear they also tried to make the combat part, but given how little importance it has I would imagine they simply didn't have the budget for it.There are two major disappointments I have with the game. Firstly, its short lenght, and secondly, the present but never developed FPS portion of the game. Seeing all the possibilities this game has on offer I was starting to think this game would be something truly amazing, with a meaning story that made you care about the characters within it, which would connect all the different missions you would embark upon. However, the sad fact is, the game ends before the first mission truly begins.With that said I can also now reveal that the whole story in the game takes place aboard an airplane (supposedly also a spaceship), and you are fully confined within it throughout the game. All the story elements come from interacting with the people within it (well, almost all), and so it is a good thing that, for the most part, they are well written and voice acted. And with a multitude of dialogue choices and possible story paths there is never a single clear choice to take, there are only the choices you want to make. That is what is most appealing about this game, and it is also what gives it replayability, despite being so heavily story focused. I am a bit disappointed with how it ended and so I won't be replaying it any time soon, only when the sequel comes out (hopefully).Perhaps the game I envisioned after a couple of hours of play could only have been achieved with a large budget, or perhaps we will get that game after all with multiple sequels of this one. Despite this, CONSORTIUM is worth buying and playing, you just need to be prepared for a fully story focused game and you'll enjoy yourself.7 / 10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												Consortium is a little bit of an odd duck - the best way I can decribe it is as a 'poor man's Mass Effect'. Both have similar main ships, both have similar multiple choice dialogue systems and both have the choices and consequences of words and actions. Consortium's graphics are very different tho, they sit firmly on the blurred line between serious and cartooney, but I personally like that. I also liked the fact that it felt like you had complete run of the ship, it felt like interactions between yourself and other crew members was more natural and less forced/scripted. I also liked the fact that lots of things were there to discover or not, it didn't really matter.On the downside, I didn't like the fact that once in a while I would feel a bit lost, not helped by the fact that some crew are 'unavailable' for interaction at certain times, without any sort of rhyme and reason. I didn't like the fact that accidently pressing the wrong key meant a conversation (and who knows how much else) was terminated and irretrievable. Even tho I liked that fact that it didn't matter to the game whether you found out stuff or not, I didn't like the fact that I finished my first runthrough with a measly 5 achievements!!All in all, a fun little (short) game with decent graphics, a decent, well thought out story with replay value and a nice little cliffhanger at the end - after all, it IS part one of a planned trilogy!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												This game is basically just a talking decision simulator. So if you want to play the dialogue from Mass Effect, but with less interesting characters, as less interesting story, and only set aboard a single ship for 4 hours, then this is the game for you. The dialogue tree is extensive and choices have impact. The combat is bad and the inventory energy system as well as the weapons don't make much sense, and poorly designed, and don't work they should half the time. The game spends all this time trying to build up this world, but things like king, queen, you, the consortium, are all poorly explained. They seem like they would be touched on in later games but aren't at this point. There are mentions to this being a video game and other things, but this game raises tons of questions and answers none of them. The murder mystery, 2/3 of the game, isn't solved at the end. Game ends right before your first actual mission. Short, kind of boring, and highly unfinished. Good dialogue system though. 5.5/10

Posted: May 9, 2014
												If I had to describe this game in a phrase, I'd say "kinda like Star Trek on a high-tech jet with Mass Effect dialog options minus persuasion stats." I could blab about what everyone else has already said, but I'll just say "ditto" to what the positive reviews are in agreement about. It's a fun experience. If you are wanting a first person shooter, I can promise you this game will not deliver on that front. You play in first person and there are a couple of parts where you may shoot, but they're pretty weak and not very good. I kinda feel like the game doesn't actually need any first person (or third) shooting at all, but I suppose that might be for the sake of empowerment and a bit of realism. Long story short, the shooting sucks, but that's almost non-existent in the game. I feel like I'm making the game sound bad, but I really liked it and will buy the sequel at launch, if/whenever that might be. The story is great and there seem to be a lot of different options and ways some events can play out. Good stuff!Take note that almost every negative review is about game-stopping bugs that supposedly no longer exist. I didn't encounter any myself now that version 1.2 is out. So think about that when considering those reviews! =)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												CONSORTIUM is an odd beast. I can honestly say I had a great time with it, and can tell that the developers put a lot of time, effort, and heart into getting this indie creation to function like it does. I'd compare it favorably to the sections in MASS EFFECT where you just chat it up with your crew on the Normandy, learn a little bit about every one, affect their lives in little ways.In CONSORTIUM, the crew is a lot less diverse (sometimes, I had trouble telling them apart), but the reactivity is absolutely fantastic. Going through the achievements, I can see so many different outcomes to choices that I made half-heartedly at the time. There's a lot of opportunity for replayablilty here. That is if you're on-board with the game's premise of spending 4-5ish hours getting to know its cast of characters in a confined flying command center.If you love the dialog/choice-heavy sections of modern RPGs, here's a great little game that's built entirely around that. As someone who always puts points into charisma in RPGs (I know, I know), CONSORTIUM was right up my alley.It's definitely not perfect. There are entire systems (inventory and ammo management) built around its very clunky combat mechanics, but I can only think of a few times when you have occasion to use your gun. You'll probably see more combat in the combat training scenario than in the rest of the game combined. It gives the impression of a game that's trying to "check a box" rather than make it a key part of the experience. It is a-okay to not have combat in a game like this. When CONSORTIUM was at its best, it reminded me of TITANIC: ADVENTURE OUT OF TIME. No combat, intriguing story, interesting characters, worthwhile investigation sections. An all-around great game.There was also a bit of story-bending to an ARG that I didn't know existed, but apparently does. In the moment, I felt a little lost, like there was a crucial part of the story I was missing.Overall, really enjoyed my experience. Confined and relatively brief, though it was, the game is also very dense. I can easily see myself playing through this a couple more times to see different outcomes. Eager to see how Part II of the trilogy eventually plays out!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Pros:+ Excellent voice acting+ Fairly interesting lore and meta story+ Simple but effective dialogue system+ Potential for completely branching story+ Warrants multiple playthroughs+ Nice sci-fi setting+ Decent graphicsCons:- Combat is so-so (though it can be completely avoided in the main story depending on your actions)- No map system (quite difficult to navigate if you haven't completely memorized the ship's layout)- Can potentially only be an hour or so's entertainment- Long loading times- Some bugs/glitches (though none game-breaking from what I've seen)CONSORTIUM is a strange little experiment which is surprisingly enjoyable. Although I consider it a hidden gem, there are definitely plenty of things that may put other people off. If you're looking for combat, look somewhere else. However, if you're looking for a short-ish experience with some decent atmosphere, characters and story, I'd say this is worth a look. I got the game for free as part of a free weekend, and I've seen it discounted as low as £2, so I would recommend getting it on sale, as the £6.99 asking price feels a little steep. Also bear in mind that if you're one for satisfying endings, this will most likely disappoint you. The ending is a cliffhanger, leaves lots of unanswered questions, and encourages you to buy the sequel; CONSORTIUM: THE TOWER (which is currently being crowdfunded (the devs have also stated that if it does not meet its target funding then the sequel will be put on hold indefinitely)) when it comes out. At a discounted price, and especially if it's free, CONSORTIUM is well worth your time.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This is a game that can easily be beaten in 5 hours or less. It would be more accurate to call this the first episode out of three than the first game out of three. The reason I say this is that there is one set of issues to be resolved in this first game in an overall arc.While to me it is a design choice, I feel that where they cut off this game from the next is probably in the wrong spot. Its like TV series that put cliffhangers in seasons when you have no idea if they will get approved for a second season. Instead they should have had it concluded with this arc all wrapped up and mostly just hinting at what comes in the next games.The graphics and voice acting for this game are very hit or miss. If you know the original Deus Ex, you have the idea. Complaints aside, this was actually a pretty fun game. It allows for multiple resolutions to situations and creating circumstances that are affected by past choices. The dialogue is at times funny and the gameply entertaining.Overall, I would say at $20 it may be a bit steep, but still worth the price. If it is on sale then it is a definite buy in my opinion if you like games with little combat and mostly npc interaction.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Tl;Dr -  A good game with a lot of potential with interesting writing and world building marred by poor combat.  Unfortunately felt like an incomplete experience that ended far too soon. Consortium is at heart an adventure/rpg tasking players with finding who the traitor is aboard an airsip and bringing them to justice.  The premise alone sounds interesting but the problem is unlike both RPGs and adventure games items in the game world are essentially just fodder to be recycled to provide power for your armor.  Despite a few times the game tryign to bring attention to certain items, at no point could they be picked up and examined making rifling through people's storage lockers and whatnot pretty pointless.  At no point did I feel like I was a detective trying to get to the bottom is a mystery but rather just going around having a casual chat with murder suspects with no actual ability to dig deeper and snoop around their personal belongings to try to contradict their stories.  As a matter of fact most snooping and gathering of information is taken from a newsfeed console that works like a text based "Her Story".  Keywords are used to search for documents and those can be read and new keywords attempted to piece together background and knowledge about characters in the world.While I liked this in Her Story I found it rather tedious in Consortium.  On the one hand, yeah it's nice to have an abundant amount of lore I can read through and learn from but on the other hand...the console isn't very well explained.  Half of the...articles?  Documents?  Whatever I'm supposed to call them are sometimes written as though they were intended to be actual posted texts and other times are written with action cues in them as if they were works of fiction or we were expected to imagine we were watching a video.  This confused tone gave the overall experience a bit of a amateurish vibe as if they weren't quite sure what they really wanted to do with with console research...so they did everything with it.  Also many documents you can search for are obviously meant to be top secret yet anyone and everyone can pull them up with relatively mundane search terms in terminals found in common areas.  I would of rather much of this information be put into the actual game world such as a paper in someone's locker or personal computer or find some notes that lead me to think they have a background in programming, search under someone's bed and find some other tidbit of information...you know...actually doing stuff with the game world.  Trying to pick up a book or examine something will simply destroy the item and recycle it's energy to power your armor as stated before which...is...mostly pointless.  It seems strange so many junk items are littered around the cramped spaces of the plane when the game has only two or maybe three combat encounters total.It also doesn't help that when these sparse combat situations happen the FPS elements are clearly lacking.   The entire experience felt as if this game had come from a past generation where early full 3D FPSes were just stepping out of Wolfenstien 3D's primordial FPS ooze.  Gunplay lacks finesse with mindless enemies running at you guns blazing with no real use of cover or indication that the people you are fighting are real people (a story trope that is hammered in a few times) but rather mindless drones sent at you like so many Doom Imps from times of yore.  You are given essentially a lethal and non lethal method of dealing with enemies but without a system in place to aid in actual non lethal combat it becomes an excercise in tedium.  Instead of methodically taking down enemies trying not to alert the hive, you're stuck with a gun having to charge blasts that may or may not take down an enemy down with very little to no feedback as to what's working and why.  Once and enemy is downed you're expected to run over to them and knock them out completely before they manage to get back up lending even more tedium to an already horrible system.  While you are given a generous amount of time to get this done, it's still very likely you're going to have to charge into the middle of the battle to try to snag all the enemies at once before they get back up leaving the rest to keep shooting you.  It's an utterly unrewarding experiance they were better off scrapping from the game entirely.Thankfully the combat is the least important part of the game as you spend most of your time wandering the plane and getting to know it's crew.  This is the meat of the gameplay and is actually done pretty well. You're expected to respond to people in a timely manner and just about everything you say is remembered and has some degree of impact later on giving a pretty good illusion of dealing with real people.  This attention to detail does come back to bite the game as you are often given a limited set of responces and have found on some occations the only sensible option was to stand there awkwardly and say nothing at all.  It's a shame the world itself wasn't given this degree of treatment as I think they could of crafted something rather special.  Each character's opinion of you is tracked seperately though I have yet to actually see this make any kind of major difference other than an indication of if they like you or not.  Only the officers in the ship seem to actually matter as you spend most of your time talking and consulting with them and some Consortium characters only appear for literally a single conversation (yet their approval is still tracked).  Replaying this game is pretty much mandatory as your first run will mostly be spent trying to figure out what the game wants from you and what you can actually do in the world to effect events going on; while this is all very well and good a full third of the game is tedious tutorial things that was interesting only the first time through yet were unskippable since.  In the end my lack of a recommendaiton came down to one thing;  The original demo for Deus Ex.  You see, throughout the entire game I kept mentally likening this to Deus Ex.  The RPG/FPS elements, the clunkiness of how just about everything works yet is not quite clunky enough to make me want to stop playing and, quite frankly, the very similar plot lines.  Deus Ex was one of my favorite games growing up and I remember being impressed by the size and length of it's demo...which was about as long as this entire game. Suffice to say I can't recommend a game that bills itself as a complete product when it's clearly geared to be an episodic release.  I have to admit the game started off on a bad foot with me when I booted it up, was immediatley told of the kickstarter for the "direct continuation".  So I just got this game and now you want funding for chapter two?  The entire plot of the game felt like it was leading to this long and epic storyline that never came.  The game just ended...on a cliffhanger no less.  A cliffhanger whose conclusion they now want me to go fund out of my pocket so I can go buy the second episode of this game.This has a lot of potential and I could gladly overlook all of the negative aspects if I felt I was given a complete game.  Unfortunately by the time I first saw those credits roll, my reaction wasn't "Man that was awesome", it was "You have to be kidding me  All that buildup to the first actual mission in the game it wasn't even IN THE GAME."  Perhaps if the plot was packaged differently and I didn't feel as though I was just railroaded into the next purchase I would be recommending this, but as it stands I just feel disappointed the game fell short of it's potential.

I'd compare it favorably to the sections in MASS EFFECT where you just chat it up with your crew on the Normandy, learn a little bit about every one, affect their lives in little ways.In CONSORTIUM, the crew is a lot less diverse (sometimes, I had trouble telling them apart), but the reactivity is absolutely fantastic. Going through the achievements, I can see so many different outcomes to choices that I made half-heartedly at the time. There's a lot of opportunity for replayablilty here. That is if you're on-board with the game's premise of spending 4-5ish hours getting to know its cast of characters in a confined flying command center.If you love the dialog/choice-heavy sections of modern RPGs, here's a great little game that's built entirely around that. As someone who always puts points into charisma in RPGs (I know, I know), CONSORTIUM was right up my alley.It's definitely not perfect. There are entire systems (inventory and ammo management) built around its very clunky combat mechanics, but I can only think of a few times when you have occasion to use your gun. You'll probably see more combat in the combat training scenario than in the rest of the game combined. It gives the impression of a game that's trying to "check a box" rather than make it a key part of the experience. It is a-okay to not have combat in a game like this. When CONSORTIUM was at its best, it reminded me of TITANIC: ADVENTURE OUT OF TIME. No combat, intriguing story, interesting characters, worthwhile investigation sections. An all-around great game.There was also a bit of story-bending to an ARG that I didn't know existed, but apparently does. In the moment, I felt a little lost, like there was a crucial part of the story I was missing.Overall, really enjoyed my experience. Confined and relatively brief, though it was, the game is also very dense. I can easily see myself playing through this a couple more times to see different outcomes. Eager to see how Part II of the trilogy eventually plays out!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Pros:+ Excellent voice acting+ Fairly interesting lore and meta story+ Simple but effective dialogue system+ Potential for completely branching story+ Warrants multiple playthroughs+ Nice sci-fi setting+ Decent graphicsCons:- Combat is so-so (though it can be completely avoided in the main story depending on your actions)- No map system (quite difficult to navigate if you haven't completely memorized the ship's layout)- Can potentially only be an hour or so's entertainment- Long loading times- Some bugs/glitches (though none game-breaking from what I've seen)CONSORTIUM is a strange little experiment which is surprisingly enjoyable. Although I consider it a hidden gem, there are definitely plenty of things that may put other people off. If you're looking for combat, look somewhere else. However, if you're looking for a short-ish experience with some decent atmosphere, characters and story, I'd say this is worth a look. I got the game for free as part of a free weekend, and I've seen it discounted as low as £2, so I would recommend getting it on sale, as the £6.99 asking price feels a little steep. Also bear in mind that if you're one for satisfying endings, this will most likely disappoint you. The ending is a cliffhanger, leaves lots of unanswered questions, and encourages you to buy the sequel; CONSORTIUM: THE TOWER (which is currently being crowdfunded (the devs have also stated that if it does not meet its target funding then the sequel will be put on hold indefinitely)) when it comes out. At a discounted price, and especially if it's free, CONSORTIUM is well worth your time.

												This game may not look like much to start... but it captures "role playing" in a way that I seldom see done well enough. Your conversations feel a little more real and emersive, and the choices you can make can quickly turn a shakey relationship sour, causing not just that character, but others to react differently in entirety, not just a small quip or comment made at somepoint, highlighting your choice for 5 seconds of "ah ha!" and then fading into obsurity like nothing really mattered in the end. The characters you interact with all have unique personalities and react like people, not exposition-spouting info logs at your disposal. In the end, I was satisfied with it. It held my interest, made me think, and didn't make me feel like I was being held by the hand and led through a tour. It was an experiece I really enjoyed.
