number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												To start:  I love this game.  But, it can be little rough at the moment.I was a backer on this game during Kickstarter, I was very intrigued at the setting, art style, and gameplay premise.  It seemed to be a unique take and full of great new ideas.  In this respect the game did not dissapoint me.  The weighted crew interactions are very well done and I found the voice work to be pretty good.  The first core gameplay centers around conversations with crew members of the Zenlil, navigating dialog trees to increase or decrease approval with different crew members and opening up new lines of inquiry and knowledge.  The second is exploring the Zenlil craft and interacting with it, though in this game it is a bit limited by what the scripting allows.  Third is the FPS combat, and in my particular playthrough it took a backseat, though depending in your actions you could get a lot more.The story and plot started off well and became more and more intrigueing as the game progressed.  It takes place in the future, where your psyche has taken possession of a soldier on the combat aircraft Zenlil of the international Consortium.  Your mind has been sent forward to this realm through a special satellite system presented as a game.  But is it really a game?  What are the true motives of those who control the system?  And what might happen if you try to test the limits of that control?  Play to find out.The world of Consortium is surprisingly deep, and there is an in-game knowledge center for those who really like to dig into the lore.  Multiple in-game hints also indicated that there is an ARG that links to the world that provides more background.  By the end I found myself with a few "Oh Wow" moments that really have me looking forward to the second Consortium game. Now for a few negatives.  Despite the tremendous quality of the game from a small indie developer, the many branching pathways and moving parts are pretty complex, and I ran into quite a few bugs right off the bat.  I began playing with the Humble Bundle download version, and it seemed to have several issues with NPC pathing, especially getting stuck in doorways, blocking access and forcing me to start over.  I also ran into situations where the scripting would get out of sync and I would, for example, get caught in a loop where I ended a conversation and then the airplane exploded, only the reload at the last save and explode again.  The solution?  Save, save, save.  Once I got into the old school habit of making an incremental save between different encounters, I was able to work around various issues and continue playing.When I got my key and changed to the Steam version, I noted it seemed to work better and several bugs present in the Humble version were not present.Overall I am extremely pleased with my decision to back these fine folks on Kickstarter and have greatly enjoyed the game.  Those who are not patient enough to deal with progress halting bugs should avoid for now, and await patches which are swiftly being worked on.  The setting is incredibly rich and begs to be expanded in future titles, which I eagerly await.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Consortium is the big boy alternative to the walking simulator.The first thing that is apparent once you start this game is the degree of bone-crushing depth to the world the developers have created. There are dozens of pages of lore contextualizing every character in the plot, every event in the meta-narrative, and the vision of the future created for this game. This is exactly what people of a certain old school demographic in gaming claim to want in an RPG, but it is instead built upon a mediocre Half Life-esque shooter's skeleton.I say that, but there is more than one path to progress through the game in which the player doesn't need to engage in combat at all. In fact, Consortium places gunplay in the back seat, leaving the plot to be the driving force. The more active gameplay is, however, still in the car, unlike other "games" lauded for their plot but devoid of anything but the simplest interactivity. There is challenge to the combat, sometimes born of the situations, sometimes born of the tight spaces of the ship or the sheer number of enemies players are expected to deal with in one fight. There are also minigames, most notably a Missle Command-esque game that, while not difficult, is engaging enough. The point is, Consortium, while focused on story, does not shun gameplay, or even the fact that it is a game. There are even dialogue options for players who wish there to be no 4th Wall at all.And the subject of dialogue options brings me to the final point in this game's favour: The degree to which the player shapes the story. Consortium is near the level of Obsidian's Alpha Protocol in terms of the permutations each event can have, and each conversation, no matter how trivial, has at least two different potential statements a player can make. This helps immensely in helping the player engage with the rest of the cast, who are all distinct in personality, and for the most part well acted, even if some performances are clearly better than others.As I said, Consortium is a big boy alternative to the walking simulator; games that use a focus on story as an excuse to be little more than a film with a few QTEs or childishly easy puzzles. It has RPG-level depth at FPS prices and is not ashamed to go into the absolute minutia about the world it seeks to build for future sequels. If those sequels stay true to this game while improving the more combat-oriented approaches, they would deserve consideration alongside the greats in the Science Fiction genre of video games.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												This game is unlike anything I've ever played.  It has stylings of other branched-dialogue games, like Mass Effect or KOTOR.  The difference is the extent to which the game respects and reacts to your choices as a player.  Your possible decisions are many, and they will change the way characters treat you, and the outcome of the game.  The world is also beautifully realized, with rich (optional) lore for your enjoyment.  After reading a small chunk of the available lore, I had a better understanding of the game world, and found myself more engaged for it.  One thing that may turn off some players is that the game will not hold your hand.  It will allow you to make mistakes and fail, which makes succeess all the more rewarding.  I recommend giving this sleeper a try - you may be pleasantly surprrised.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I had my doubts about this game - there is quite a lot of negative reviews regarding game's performance, mechanics, stability. But during the last winter sale I've decided to give it a try. And the only thing I regret is not playing it earlier.It may not be a game for everyone. There are games that are longer, prettier, even deeper. But what "Consortium" IS - it's a great role-playing game. Not in the sense of tweaking your character's characteristics, but rather of living another life, while remaining yourself (literally - you are playing as yourself, only after being implanted into a different body). You choose your own actions and behavior, line of actions - and face the consequences.  Act kindly, aggressively, funny, try to flirt or impose discipline - and see the crew of Zenlil-2 react. You can even choose to reveal your true identity. Or act neturally, learning of how this new world works and adapting to its rules.Second part of the game is coming to KS soon - and I myself am waiting for a possibility to live in that world a bit more.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												A beautifully well-written game. It throws you in the deep end plot-wise, but that is actually a plus for this game as you work out just what kind of situation in. Quickly into the plot, it develops into mysterious and, for once, actually believable mystery game. The one (or two, depending on your choices, I hear) proper shooting sequence has mechanics decent enough to make it enjoyable and I assume it's a taste test for the sequel, which will likely have more. Kudos to the developer for making the mystery cohesive and giving the player a truly stumping series of events. I only got it right because I noticed the culprit doing some dodgy acts before the investigation. The culprit was believable and I did not find myself irritated by any cliches. The plotline thankfully avoids many, many cliches. It is also brilliantly well acted, and the variance of accents really gives it a feeling of a futuristic, almost united world. The plot also reminds me of 1984, and gives the player perfect reason to support any of the factions (or neither, like me). I find most games flop when they try to write as intricate plot as this, either falling into cliche or simply being way too over its head to be coherent or well written. This game, however, does it well and gets a high reccomendation from me. A little short, but still well worth the investment. Can't wait for the sequel.By the way, your choices change a lot. Unlike most games *cough cough* Telltale's Game of Thrones *cough cough*, every choice is significant and you also know when a significant decision must be made. You understand the severity of the events at all time and the game throughout is very intense. I'm so glad this game did its choices and consequences right.

												Aweful, aweful game. First playthrough expect to spend *alot* of time in the dark, literally and metaphorically. Some objectives are very vague, some are so easy to fail simply because you didn't notice something, some seem to be impossible to pass. Examples, I was told to "defend the crew", shot or incapacitated maybe 8 attackers, 2 of them standing infront of a wall yelling but not moving, searched the entire plane and couldn't find anyone else, objective is still the same 15 mins later. Ummm... huh? Reload game from the last auto save, this time 12 attackers where I found the first 8 and I move on. Okay so major bugs in that mission that they didn't fix.Another mission I am supposed to rescue the pilot when he is at risk of being electrocuted. Objective says to go through the access point in the cockpit. I do that and people are yelling "help him! quick! get out of there!" I look around, it's a small room with an access door that I came through and a door to the infirmary where some of the people are yelling, but the door is locked. I think "okay, they already got him to the infirmary and I am supposed to go there. I go back through the cockpit and people really freak out. "Go back in there and help him!" Except now the access point is locked. Oooookay? what was that about? Second playthrough I find out he is in the corner of that small room. That would have been nice to know before you wasted my time.Another easy to fail mission because they didn't make things clear, those 8 attackers that I said I found in that mission? That was technically my second time playing that mission. the first time I was told to follow a crew member to a weapons lockup. she walks 20 feet and a door opens, she turns and looks at me, I walk through the door, it closes and locks behind me. Huh? she didn't follow? where are my weapons? The objectives just read "protect the crew" and tell me to go to the hanger bay. I go there, unarmed, and think alright I'm supposed to knock out an attacker and take his gun. nope, punching them does nothing. I spend another 5 mins searching for that mysterious weapons catch I was promised, no where to be found. Reload, Oh! she was walking up to (and blocking) a small panel built into the wall with some weapons, and I'm not supposed to go through the door, just wait until she opens it. lame.Finally a mission that I'm apparently not supposed to succeed? I'm supposed to convince the pilot that there is a virus in the system. Ok, easy! Except when I get the mission I am standing next to the cockpit door and it is locked. A woman walks in and locks it behind her again. You can see through a "window" to one side and they are making out, they tell you to go away and there is nothing else to do. The woman doesn't come out until you leave the area, and when you return the pilot is already down below where he gets electrocuted, so you are notified that you failed the mission. Oookay? So why is that even a mission?Oh yeah, so as for being in the dark literally, for some reason you spend at least 30% of the game in near or total darkness because the lights are malfunctioning. As you can imagine, that makes it a bit difficult to navigate the ship, especially with out a map, since sometimes you have no idea if you are even moving or just stuck at a poorly made doorway that you have to walk at just right to walk through.Now a word on game length. I've played through twice. 7 hours on record. The first playthrough took over 5 irritating hours of being left in the dark wondering "what am I supposed  to be doing?" Which means the second playthrough, now that I know what I'm doing, only took 2 hours even though I tried different options and unlocked some things that either weren't available or simply bugged during the first playthrough.Finally, the game has a few bugs. Some of them irrelevant, like the pilot saying that he is going to check some systems, you go into the cockpit and he is sitting in the air acting like he is pushing buttons 5 feet from his chair. Some of the glitches halt your progress, like the 2 enemies staring at and pointing their guns at the wall while yelling at you then nobody else shows up and you can't move on.Overall, a terrible game. I'll try it once or twice more to make sure I'm not missing something major that caused others to give this game a high rating, but it looks like it's a waste of time.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Tl;Dr -  A good game with a lot of potential with interesting writing and world building marred by poor combat.  Unfortunately felt like an incomplete experience that ended far too soon. Consortium is at heart an adventure/rpg tasking players with finding who the traitor is aboard an airsip and bringing them to justice.  The premise alone sounds interesting but the problem is unlike both RPGs and adventure games items in the game world are essentially just fodder to be recycled to provide power for your armor.  Despite a few times the game tryign to bring attention to certain items, at no point could they be picked up and examined making rifling through people's storage lockers and whatnot pretty pointless.  At no point did I feel like I was a detective trying to get to the bottom is a mystery but rather just going around having a casual chat with murder suspects with no actual ability to dig deeper and snoop around their personal belongings to try to contradict their stories.  As a matter of fact most snooping and gathering of information is taken from a newsfeed console that works like a text based "Her Story".  Keywords are used to search for documents and those can be read and new keywords attempted to piece together background and knowledge about characters in the world.While I liked this in Her Story I found it rather tedious in Consortium.  On the one hand, yeah it's nice to have an abundant amount of lore I can read through and learn from but on the other hand...the console isn't very well explained.  Half of the...articles?  Documents?  Whatever I'm supposed to call them are sometimes written as though they were intended to be actual posted texts and other times are written with action cues in them as if they were works of fiction or we were expected to imagine we were watching a video.  This confused tone gave the overall experience a bit of a amateurish vibe as if they weren't quite sure what they really wanted to do with with console research...so they did everything with it.  Also many documents you can search for are obviously meant to be top secret yet anyone and everyone can pull them up with relatively mundane search terms in terminals found in common areas.  I would of rather much of this information be put into the actual game world such as a paper in someone's locker or personal computer or find some notes that lead me to think they have a background in programming, search under someone's bed and find some other tidbit of information...you know...actually doing stuff with the game world.  Trying to pick up a book or examine something will simply destroy the item and recycle it's energy to power your armor as stated before which...is...mostly pointless.  It seems strange so many junk items are littered around the cramped spaces of the plane when the game has only two or maybe three combat encounters total.It also doesn't help that when these sparse combat situations happen the FPS elements are clearly lacking.   The entire experience felt as if this game had come from a past generation where early full 3D FPSes were just stepping out of Wolfenstien 3D's primordial FPS ooze.  Gunplay lacks finesse with mindless enemies running at you guns blazing with no real use of cover or indication that the people you are fighting are real people (a story trope that is hammered in a few times) but rather mindless drones sent at you like so many Doom Imps from times of yore.  You are given essentially a lethal and non lethal method of dealing with enemies but without a system in place to aid in actual non lethal combat it becomes an excercise in tedium.  Instead of methodically taking down enemies trying not to alert the hive, you're stuck with a gun having to charge blasts that may or may not take down an enemy down with very little to no feedback as to what's working and why.  Once and enemy is downed you're expected to run over to them and knock them out completely before they manage to get back up lending even more tedium to an already horrible system.  While you are given a generous amount of time to get this done, it's still very likely you're going to have to charge into the middle of the battle to try to snag all the enemies at once before they get back up leaving the rest to keep shooting you.  It's an utterly unrewarding experiance they were better off scrapping from the game entirely.Thankfully the combat is the least important part of the game as you spend most of your time wandering the plane and getting to know it's crew.  This is the meat of the gameplay and is actually done pretty well. You're expected to respond to people in a timely manner and just about everything you say is remembered and has some degree of impact later on giving a pretty good illusion of dealing with real people.  This attention to detail does come back to bite the game as you are often given a limited set of responces and have found on some occations the only sensible option was to stand there awkwardly and say nothing at all.  It's a shame the world itself wasn't given this degree of treatment as I think they could of crafted something rather special.  Each character's opinion of you is tracked seperately though I have yet to actually see this make any kind of major difference other than an indication of if they like you or not.  Only the officers in the ship seem to actually matter as you spend most of your time talking and consulting with them and some Consortium characters only appear for literally a single conversation (yet their approval is still tracked).  Replaying this game is pretty much mandatory as your first run will mostly be spent trying to figure out what the game wants from you and what you can actually do in the world to effect events going on; while this is all very well and good a full third of the game is tedious tutorial things that was interesting only the first time through yet were unskippable since.  In the end my lack of a recommendaiton came down to one thing;  The original demo for Deus Ex.  You see, throughout the entire game I kept mentally likening this to Deus Ex.  The RPG/FPS elements, the clunkiness of how just about everything works yet is not quite clunky enough to make me want to stop playing and, quite frankly, the very similar plot lines.  Deus Ex was one of my favorite games growing up and I remember being impressed by the size and length of it's demo...which was about as long as this entire game. Suffice to say I can't recommend a game that bills itself as a complete product when it's clearly geared to be an episodic release.  I have to admit the game started off on a bad foot with me when I booted it up, was immediatley told of the kickstarter for the "direct continuation".  So I just got this game and now you want funding for chapter two?  The entire plot of the game felt like it was leading to this long and epic storyline that never came.  The game just ended...on a cliffhanger no less.  A cliffhanger whose conclusion they now want me to go fund out of my pocket so I can go buy the second episode of this game.This has a lot of potential and I could gladly overlook all of the negative aspects if I felt I was given a complete game.  Unfortunately by the time I first saw those credits roll, my reaction wasn't "Man that was awesome", it was "You have to be kidding me  All that buildup to the first actual mission in the game it wasn't even IN THE GAME."  Perhaps if the plot was packaged differently and I didn't feel as though I was just railroaded into the next purchase I would be recommending this, but as it stands I just feel disappointed the game fell short of it's potential.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												When I saw this game being free for a weekend I thought to myself "Probably another mediocre, sci-fi Shooter". After finishing this game in one session, I realized that I couldn't have been more wrong.CONSORTIUM is best compaired with story-rich First Person games like the original Deus Ex or the Mass Effect series. First, I'll get to the games strongest points. The Story is kinda weird, but in an awesome way. You make up your own background story, your seekings and how your attitude. Since you are in an to you unknown world, this leads to some comical missunderstanding, both showing a great humor and sometimes breaking the 4th wall. There are also no cutscenes in this game, never robbing you of its control and always being able to decide whether you want to be nice to someone, ♥♥♥♥ them off, just walk away from a conversation or simply staying silent. There are a lot of choices and interessting stuff to explore that you will miss in your first playthrough. In addition, most characters are enough fleshed out to be interessting and have an own personality.If you are searching for a good shooter, CONSORTIUM might not be the right choice as I found the combat system and ammo managment to be kinda confusion. It works for the time being but has much room for improvements. If you want a great story, great characters, many choices and an awesome time, get it. An amazing masterpiece that only Indiedevelopers can bring forth.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Well, at least its got cards...Terrible gameplay, graphics from the late 90's and awful performance.Interaction with NPCs and objects works basically on and off. If a door opens once, don't expect it to open again by interacting with it from the exact same angle; go take a walk, come back and it will (hopefully) then open. Same with NPCs, even worse when you have to either incapacitate or heal them. Weapons behave weirdly and not very dynamic; the whole combat system doesn't feel very intuitive and up for the challenge; add to that the fact that this game is so poorly optmized that playing it gives me headaches.Also, the lack of a map with objective marks makes for a hellishly infuriating experience, especially on missions where time is key for completion. How the hell am I supposed to know where all the rooms in the ship are by name? How can I know where I'm heading to? Also, how am I supposed to know I'm some sort of "time traveler" if there's no background explanation and no hint about it? Some of the dialog choices makes no sense, and seem to be more appropriate for end game rather than beginning.It's a real shame that this game didn't really take off and they're basically giving it away at just about every indie game website. It had potential, and someone did put a lot of work into the story, and also the voice acting is quite decent.It kind of angers me when part of a team puts in all the work, and the other half (usually made of unmotivated, uncaring, often inexperienced individuals) simply makes no effort to dish out a decent product.I cannot really NOT recommend it, but since Steam is so avant-garde as to offer reviewers the option to stay neutral (yes, sarcasm...), I'll have to say NO.Sure get it if you like, but only for free like I did... or very, very cheap. No way it's worth 10 bucks.EDIT: I was just having another go, and five minutes in, I was hit by 3 NPCs chatting to me at the same time, with their voice-overs on top of each other. Made it impossible to know what answer to choose for one of them because I couldn't understand what was asked.EDIT 2: Hit by another bug, it happens when you manage to trap the traitor in one of the bedrooms or in the area that goes towards the medical bay: the traitor freezes up, doesn't move or shoot you, and both his health and stamina bar doesn't deplete as you keep shooting him, even after you depleted his armor. You have to get out of the way and let him go, so the combat resumes normally.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Consortium nails the communication with NPC part of RPGs.  If you enjoy the conversation part of games like Mass Effect but want it to be more meaningful you will love this game.  Unfortunately the combat is sparse, flat and buggy and the animations cartoonish.  The voice acting is decent which is huge since that’s most of the game.  On my first attempt I ended up in a shootout after a bunch of talking to NPCs, however there was a bug and the NPC bad guy was shooting before I even got close, so I started over.  On my second attempt I noticed that my changes in dialog really affected the direction of the story, unfortunately the story and dialog choices never interested me and I never felt engaged in my role, felt more like I was part of a Saturday morning cartoon world.  In addition the bugs and cartoony graphics really killed the immersion for me, which in a game where you spend most of the time talking to NPCs without immersion there is really no point.  I ended up getting bored and moved on to other games. Consortium is alright I guess to see how conversation trees leading to different paths should be done, and I hope all the devs and talent involved in that aspect catch on with other studiosn (cough...bioware...cough) and impart some of Consortiums success on to big budget games in RPGs when it comes to dialog.  But as a game in its own right nailing the conversation aspect of RPGs only gets you so far when every other aspect of the game is bland or broken.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												CONSORTIUM is exactly the kind of game that I have wanted for years and yet it misses the mark so badly. You find yourself as a player transported into the body of someone in another dimension (yes just like Nomad Soul) who is kind of a heavy gunner type assassin for the crew of a high tech Bowing747. The idea for the game seems to have been to throw crises at the crew and allow the player in an interactive fiction type way to be an instrumental part of the crews survival, with a combination of free roaming, actions on the ship, dialogue and if the player wants to, combat.Your experience here is short without any completed story arcs, not that the game is long enough to do a good one. The poor writing starts when you are thrown into a world without any boot strapping to tell you anything about what is going on. I only became comfortable with the organisation I was working for and even knew what my character's role on the ship was after doing some reading outside of the game, after my first play through. The dialogue is poor, mainly because the characters lack real depth, the events in the game are pulled right from badly written 90's films (Under Siege 1992). Combat is clunky, when there is combat, and the combat simulator missions are unfinished and not, fun.This game has so many bugs! And I played the 1.2 Master Edition which is a re-release, as the first version contained a lot of bugs. CONSORTIUM does not feel like a well tested or polished experience. This really needed more time in development. The component parts are here, but it hasn't been crafter or polished into a fine product.3/5

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Consortium is a sci-fi'ish game set in the near future (there's more to it than that, but that's the easiest way to classify it). You play as Bishop 6 quite literally. It's a meta sort of thing, though that's not spoilers. The Good: I loved the plot and the character interaction. It reminded me a lot of Mass Effect 2 in that regard, but with more life to it because people aren't always in the exact same spots. The graphics are nothing special, but they do fit with the art style. I loved that every choice in this game seemed to matter (we'll have to wait until part 2 to see how much), but it was nice to see immediate consequences and not just a change in an arbitrary karma bar llike some games. Yes, I'm looking at you Mass Effect 2. Speaking of a sort of karma bar, there isn't one, at least not one visible to the player and I for one loved it for that. As long as it's done well having no number attached to your actions that the player can see makes it mroe immersive and stops the player from "counting karma". The choices make a difference and aren't just things referenced in one line of dialogue lateer and forgot. A lot of your choices determine who lives and who dies, a thing most games are afraid to do and save for the last minutes of a game. The Bad: Glitches. There are quite a few, but there's nothing that can't be fixed fairly easily. Aside from the game crashing when you alt-tab, there's no crash related bugs I've encountered. I run two 660 ti's in sli so I fully expected crashed and other stupid stuff, but it never came to that. The framerate is a bit choppy and others have mentioned it as well. I don't know if that's because of sli or just some other weirdness. It wasn't ever bad enough to where I couldn't play the game. It's a bit on the short side for 19.99, but I think the replayability makes up for it. Going through the game again with vastly different choices should have a huge effect on the story and make your game completely different.The Ugly; I don't really have anything for this section. There aren't any really bad bugs, at least nothing on the scale of bluescreening or anything that severe. In summary I loved this game. It is a little weird, but if you like the idea of a plot driven game then this is it. By plot driven game I mean it's not like most games where they wait for you forever and ever. This game will go on without you to a certain extent, but not to the point of where you feel like you're being dragged behind a car. I would say right now, get it on the sale that is going (at the time of this review) if you think you might want to try it and then wait for a patch. Like I mentioned before the glitches aren't super bad, but they may irritate some people. The developers seem quick on the uptatke and seem to care about fixing the bugs however. :)

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												Consortium is a FPS/RPG, a bit akin to Deus Ex as the setting is futuristic, there is an inventory system with a character sheet, multiple lines of dialog to choose from, and a sub-par shooting experience.In Consortium, the player "controls" a soldier in an intervention outfit. There is a very interesting hierarchy in that group, as if each person was a chess piece. The game takes place in the aircraft of that outfit undergoing an assault from an enemy militia. Discussing with anyone lets the player choose how they respond (play dumb, flirt, and so on) and stand in a positive or negative way relative to each character. The dialogs are to me the meat of the game, quite interesting with well fleshed out characters.Sadly, the First Person Shooting is so bad that I could not go much further in the game. Enemies have too much health and the combat is stiff and uninteresting. There are lots of opponents that can easily pin down the player (the combat takes place in an enclosed space), and it feels frustrating that such a bad shooting experience is also so difficult to overcome.Overall I think the game is an interesting and well written piece, but the FPS part is so badly executed that it prevents from appreciating the rest of the experience.

It is built around a single puzzle, which is solved after gathering information from several sources.If you wanted to read a story, you'd get an actual book. content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												**Worst Indie Game Experience to date**The fact they want $14 is a hilarious joke, you get 3 hours of gameplay at it if you go REALLY slow. I got this when it was FREE and feel like I need to be compensated for wasting my time on my horrible Source-engine simulator.I normally just do TLDR reviews so see below:Pros:-NoneCons:-Horrible scripting-Buggy as all get out, I had several instances where the storyline bugged because a trigger I walked over would replay a conversation between various NPCs I'd done an hour ago-Horrendous animations-Only one instance where you actually shoot a gun-Again, the pricetag.To sum up, this game is NOT an RPG, it's NOT a simulator, it's definitely Indie but beyond that this plays like a couple of teenagers pulled up the Source SDK over their summer break and cranked this joke of a game out.And guess what popped up as soon as I launched the game after getting it for FREE? A bloody "Hey back us up on KICKSTARTER FOR CONSORTIUM: THE TOWER!"I've never felt like contacting Valve/Steam over being ripped off, but if I'd bought this game for $15 when it came out I would've seriously taken it up with Valve to get my money back. You get 3hours of gameplay, there's no point in replaying it to see if you could've "Done things differently" like in KOTOR or Mass Effect.Simply put, don't waste your time.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												The controls are, oddly, split between controller, mouse, and keyboard. You can do 80% of things using the controller, but navigation of the inventory menu requires a mouse and jumping requires a keyboard. It's a fairly useless support of controllers why basic, critical actions require two extra peripherals to be accomplished.Beyond that, the game gives very little direction of where to go. Mission objectives flash briefly the screen, only to be forever lost once the dialog disappears (and it will disappear quickly, often before you have time to read it). Even if you do manage to catch what your objective is, there's no map or directional indicator to help you know where to go to accomplish the objective.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												This is a post-patch revisitation review. It contains no plot-revelation spoilers.Consortium is a game I very much enjoyed, and I plan to play the future installments, but the game is also a victim of its own ambitions in certain ways.The game concepts and mechanics are often novel and welcome, and the dedication to rpg storytelling is evident and appreciated.And yet ...... not all of the storytelling concepts are executed as well as someone seems to think they are. Nowhere is this more evident than in the mystery featured in chapter one.You are charged by your superiors to investigate the possibility of a traitor aboard the Consortium aircraft. I spent real-time hours trying to perform due diligence on the investigation; reading files; questioning suspects; and the like.The end result was only mountains of contradictory "evidence" any court would dismiss as circumstantial at best. Certainly not enough to assuredly accuse anyone, let alone convict them.To compound the problem, even though you are investigating on the authority of the three ranking Consortium members aboard the aircraft, potential suspects routinely evade lines of questioning, or are flat-out uncooperative (however politely) -- even though everyone tells you that they want to see the problem solved.Worst of all, the very people who set you to investigating shut you down when you complain of lack of cooperation -- but subsequently demand you produce a suspect, and express annoyance when you refuse to offer someone up on little more than a hunch based on circumstantial evidence.It ends up making your superiors seem corrupt at worst, and heavy-handed fools at best. On my first playthrough save, I actually resigned from the Consortium over this.I only solved the mystery thanks to a hint a fellow player gave me -- when you first arrive aboard the aircraft, look around. Someone appears to be working in a place which may later prove to be ... problematic.None of my detective work led me to the suspect. Only this.So, yes, Consortium is an enjoyable, and often novel, take on the rpg genre, and worth its price (in my opinion) -- but the game's clever systems and techniques are only as good as the content powering them -- and someone needed to spend a little more time inside the mystery plot to insure that it hung together as well as they believed it did.When you succeed in drawing the player into your game-world -- as Consortium did with me -- it's important that the game world maintain its plausibility and consistency once the player has engaged.My opinions, anyway,

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												The game is just coming out and I was hooked when they showed off an internal view of the air ship.  The game litterally puts you in control of a character aboard an airship.  You play "Bishop" aboard of crew ranked by chess pieces.  Acting as the 2nd in command to the Knight, your job is to ensuring the crews moral and ship safety.  The voice acting is great, the story well written and the game allows the player to make decisions that affect the outcome of the story and how the crew likes/hates you.  What is one of the more stand out moments of the game is the fact that while YOU, the player, view this as a game.  The characters view the world as "Reality".  So you juggle between all the past experiences normally seen in a games cliche story arch and the "reality" of the world in which you present.Now the game is still with glitches and bugs.  But the developers have rescently released a notice stating they are aware of this and apolgiesed for any inconveniances.  Which is a bonus in my book when a developer owns up to their mistakes and spends time too work everything out.This game is worth a buy.  With a multitude of outcomes based on your actions, the replay is high.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I was very very impressed by this game. At first I thought that it was not going to be that good, I thought the action was gonna be dull and you were going to be stuck in long monolagues forever. That, however, was not the case. Even though the storyline and voice acting as well as the flow of the conversations you have (which also has a really interesting reputation system) was amazing to say the least (I would compare and even would dare to say that it puts mass effect to shame), the action comes at you early, hard, and fast, and boy is it a kicker. I definatley would recommend this game and If I had a rating system I would give it a 10/10 because I have not found a game that has surprised me and kept me excited like this since Far Cry 3, and setting this apart from Far Cry 3 it is a truly original and new expirience that I think could start a whole new crave for these kinds of games kind of how Minecraft did for Voxel Sandboxes.

												Without question, this has been one of my most enjoyed entertainment experiences to date. The story is excellent, the world is well fleshed out, the characters are unique and believable... Its like a Telltale Games adventure but you get to jump in guns blazing to be the hero at times as well. I'm so hopeful that the sequel will come around because I'm enthralled enough that I need closure on this, and just more games like this in general. I could not reccommend this highly enough to other gamers who value an engrossing experience. There were a few graphical glitches and gameplay/physics bugs that would normally have been a bit infuriating but, in this context, I just didn't care; they couldn't detract from the rest of the wonderful time spent in this gem of a game.[Edit] I've just finished a second playthrough and now I'm even more in love. content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												I really like the approach of making the user essentially a character in the story. It's a unique perspective for the game to take. The story is solid, the characters are interesting, and I like what they are doing here conceptually.In practice, it doesn't make for a great game. It wants you to read through exhaustive articles to pick up little bits of information. It wants you to replay the same game multiple times in order to pick up on a reasonable chunk of the story and content. It can be confusing to navigate the ship when they frantically yell at you to go to some area with an unclear location. Other than to appear Mass Effect-like, I don't know why they chose to utilize a first person engine. The combat and inventory are exceedingly clunky. Going with an RPG style or even menu based system would probably fit the overall game better.It's interesting and I'm glad that I played it, but I wouldn't recommend it to others. Without a smoother gameplay experience, I'm not eager to play the sequel to continue the story when it comes out.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I think this game has amazing potential, but mediocre application. If you play the game for the first time, you'll be ridicously excited about the different possibilities in the game. You'll enjoy it. Perhaps so much that this will be worth the price of the game alone. However...If you replay it to discover the differences in the game, and try to get a different outcome, you'll realize you've been cheated into thinking that all these possibilities were there, when in fact they were illusionary.  (It's as if the Stanley Parable only had dead ends in all but one path) Your role in any replay will vary only very slighty from your first playthrough, and let's face it: the value of this game is the freedom and your role in the story.Summary: This game could've been revolutionary, instead its passable and forgettable. I would not recommend it to anyone, but also hope they continue the franchise with major improvements.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												Consortium is a short adventure game set in a Thunderbirds TV series-like environment, nice story, terrible game.The game is worth a try, devs put a real effort into it and clearly cared, but I don't think I'll play it again.Pros (where all the efforts were put to good use)a rich branching dialogueseveral possible endingsSci-Fi background storyvery good voice actingcons (where the lack of experience shows)all characters look the same, same build, same head, but different hair colourdialogues overlap, you are talking with a character and various messages inform you of other (important ?) events, not easy to listen to two people at onceno sync between dialogues and subtitles, they disappear before the character says them, and if a character talks quickly OR if several events happen at the same time, subtitles lag behinda count down limits time to read the dialogue options (???)screen shaking – in the future planes still fly like♥♥♥♥♥♥(hate this feature, in any game)screen blurring – communication with the past is tricky, right, but horizontal lines every thirty seconds are  just annoyingmovement is awkward, characters push you aside when walking, they block your path in the corridors (there are only corridors), invisible walls block your movement, crouching is painfully slow, invisible walls slow you even more, even entering a room is trickycontrary to what the game says, you do not need any FPS experience, as combat is nonexistent – also your class is fightersome missions have count down timers you are unaware of, you’ll discover them when you fail the missionthe game forces you to act quickly and use techniques you never practiced – maybe once in the simulatoryour character doesn't evolve, this is no RPG for me

Posted: May 18, 2014
												I have suspected this for a while, but I can conclued that the best games do in fact come from Canada.The ending hyped me for the possible sequel immediatly. I love this game's atmosphere. Its plot line can be compared to that of Telltale's The Walking Dead, it was ultimately linear, but your choices did matter. I would even go as far as to say the developers surpassed Telltale here. Screw Metascore this time. This game has the potential to be at least as great as Bioware's Mass Effect or Valve's own Half-Life. I can only semi-complain about the cliff-hanger at the end, so I must beg the developers to please actually release a second part, (Half-Life 3 anytime soon, Valve?) I feel as if this concept can be greatly expanded upon.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Consortium tends to play like an adventure/detective title, with branching dialouge options and Alternate Reality Game based lore, and a smattering of FPS elements thrown in.  And by "branching" I mean "be warned, your decisions and actions will *actually matter* in this game!", which already makes it rather unique.Movement through the certain areas of the ship tends to be a bit awkward, due to the realisticly cramped quarters, but the overall design is very well put together.  You will be challenged with the exploration and usage of the detailed "micro-environment" setting you find youself in, and forced to make quick descions based on instinct and whatever information you can glean from your surroundings or the NPCs.  Combat is not a huge portion of the game, though tends to be intense when it does happen.  As for the storyline... without giving away too much, it's about as twisty and complicated as they come, with a MASSIVE amount of backstory to flesh things out.Overall it's a good game with a unique design and plot, where one can wind up exploring a small yet incrediably detailed worldsetting.  I'd reccomend it as a purchase for anyone.

content:

												-THIS IS NOT AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW-This game is something really great. I've waited for the final release of the game, for all the bugs to fix, and, unlike the other weird people, I reviewed the final release the game. Generally gameplay reminds me of System Shock 2, bit of Deus Ex and bit of first Half Life too. Speaking of Half Life, and fighting by the way, all the game can be finished without firing a single bullet - conversation is of course the most important thing here -  or of course you can fight your way through the game, and doing that be carefull when you firing grenades - you are in a pretty BIG aircraft, you know what I mean and yes - I tried this once and almost flew away through the hole i made :d Combat is though. Even on a easiest level, it's still challenging. But, I am sure that the great characters, interesting plot with many things to discover, (not through the first gameplay - i've played two times and everytime the game was MUCH different as I was choosing other options and deeds), a LOT of dialogues with a perfect voice acting and dubbing will convince you to check this out.PS. I don't care about how the game looks, Consortium is poor in graphics but pretty rich in other stuff. Go play Far Cry 3 if you want good looking games and don't even try this in that case.

												The first great game of 2014! This game has personality and it shows in every interaction. The scope of the game may be small but the details keep you wanting more and many of the actions you take really feel like they are impacting the rest of the game. Like the great RPGs of old you can complete the game without killing anyone and be a saint to your crew mates or a silent killing machine feared and respected by everyone you come across. The only downsides are that combat can get clunky at times and the color blue is a bit overused. Imaginitive and unique Consortium is a fantastic fist person experience that can be played over and over again.

												Well I don't have a lot to say about this Title, it has OK Graphics, So/So Shootermechanics and a Good RPG System. The Lore is extensive and the decisions you make are plentyful and yield high impact on Gameplay and your Surroundings. For someone who has not played it's Predecessor the Lore is a little Hard to understand but if you are Willing to listen and read you get dragged into a Lorerich Universe.The Game is very well thought throug, it has a lot of Secrets to find, although the Surrounding you can explore is limited.This one is very very Hard to recommend without spoiling, but this should be for you if:- You like an immersive Gameplay- You like reading lots and lots of lore.- You like to be praised if you do something well and scolded if you're acting evil.You will dislike the Game if:-You're looking for a shooter-You're looking for next-Gen-Hardcore Graphics-You're looking for a Falloutclone. (It has nothing in Common although both have weapons and dialouge, this one is wayy heavier on the dialouge and Choices)-You like scanning for life signs (if you play it, you'll get this joke)I enjoyed my Consortium Expirience and I am looking forward to the next Episode.

												This game is shockingly short, but the storytelling more than makes up for it. In just 5 hours of gameplay, I actually beat the game while realizing that there is much more inside of it...The music is outstanding, the character voices are wonderful (Aside from a certain blabbermouth, but I think that's intentional) and the only major problem I had with most of the scenes was them waving their hands in the air as if they are constantly typing on a holo-screen.For five hours of gameplay, I successfully saved lives, and failed at the plot. But there are no bad choices in this game (Aside from standing still under fire...) and my best choice is rating it 8.5/10.I just wish I realized it was a trilogy before I bought it...SIDE EDIT: Just remembered, this was made in Source, the next is gonna be Unreal, just like how much they pulled out of the first engine.

												Great game. Has that Quantum Leap Feel to it. Minus the Fact that your controlling another person via remote control for the most part.The game is worth it for a laugh and doesn't spoon feed you anything, that you should know while taking over the person your in. You get the control prompts and tool tips required to navigate the hud.But, anything else is for the most part you are so and so and you got to fill in the blank with out Al or Ziggy giving you any help you would expect from the TV series.You have to play the game like you attempting to solve a mystery, and remember everything as best as possible. You will find if you play a certain way you won't catch any one off guard because your taking the role of a new transfer to a ship. Clearly you don't know anything the first time playing, and so helps soften the blow for your first time playing through.Is the game worth it. Yes if you enjoy reading into things and documenting things personally yourself.Get the game and Enjoy the Talkies and Virtual Simulator Challenges.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												A great game for those that love interactive stories in their games. Good writing, good characterization, and good voice acting come together to make a solid piece of video game storytelling. There are plenty of permutations in the story to justify multiple playthroughs, and your choices genuinely affect the way the story plays out. Considering the fact that there are so few games like this that focus on player choice, it's good to not only see it released, but to see that it is done very well, and in a unique way. For this alone, I would recommend the game. Though the game contains combat, there isn't very much of it. This is a bit odd considering how much detail they tried to put into the system. In the higher difficulty levels, individual parts of your suit and body can be damaged, and you can repair/heal those specific parts. There's even an inventory system, wherein you can trade energy (which is used for repairs and energy weapons) for physical space to carry guns, ammo, etc.Despite this level of detail, it isn't particularly polished. The AI spews fire everywhere while running around like headless chickens, and the inventory system is more annoying than it's really worth. The creators of the game either had a grander vision than they were able to actually execute, or they are just trying to establish the skeleton of the combat system for the future titles.Don't get me wrong, the combat isn't unplayable or unfun, it's just nothing particularly special. This is not a AAA FPS.It's also worthy to note that, when this game was first released, it had several game-breaking bugs. However, the vast majority of the bugs have been mopped up now, and I have had no trouble since the first few patches they released to fix the major bugs.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Just got done playing CONSORTIUM after picking it up in the humble bundle, I heard good things about it and this is what I took away from my experience.Great-Characters, pacing, atmosphereThe characters are written well with their own motives and quirks, without being transparent enough to feel like an NPC. Pacing of these interactions and the overall plot are not bad at all, and when combined with the setting deliver a game you can jump into and feel hooked. I personally enjoyed the voiceacting and sound design.Alright-Play length and amount of content to experience on a single playthrough leaves something to be desired, don't blow your horn about a trilogy if they're all going to be this quick and rely on multiple playthroughs to deliver full circle. Content is one thing, double handling gets old after awhile. I appreciate that we have many choices, but some of them lack follow through if you play certain types of characters. Sometimes there is no foothold for a player with too much intuition that will scour out of the way areas.Lore dumps-the lore contained in this game is handcrafted and certainly interesting. The only problem outside of limited audio broadcasts/conversations is that if you want to experience any of it-have fun reading codex lore dumps in the menu. No offense but it was more fun to fly by the seat of my pants than do that and try to figure anything out, which seems to be a huge waste. Why gate so much great stuff behind one of the dullest interactions in your game?Plain bad-Shooting, Inventory management, sense of progression, jaggy shadowsThis is a game worth playing but it feels at times if it is grasping for too many things to have that "feature list" that tends to accompany recent steam releases. The shooting is just plain bad(especially if you want to play non-killing), the hud sucks for it. If you want to play a decent shooter don't come into Consortium expecting even that. To make the matter worse any inventory management feels like it is there just to be there. Most of the items I encountered had no practical use inside the story, and anytime I did use a weapon/ammo/armor it was unintuitive, a huge hassle, and most of all not even fun. These two areas need some polish or even to be redone completely if you want to really tout them as cornerstones of the gameplay experience. Which leads to my next point-progression. At the end of the day I felt like I made a difference, and was a set piece for some cool stuff. Even though I kept being swept along to the next issue there were a few "AHA" experiences in the plot or character interactions which left me wanting more. But you still feel very gated off from what is really happening, with few avenues to approach it in an otherwise very thoughtful and ambitious setup. Also the shadow jaggies are downright terrible, expect them to be a bit jarring even if you have a nicer PC. My final comments will be aimed at the developer review-you need to decide on what you want and get it right the first time, and budget the appropriate timelines and resources to it. There is a vocal audience that bought into this game when it released, and you can tell they felt let down by the compromises and changes you made to the content and schedule. I can believe how buggy the initial playthroughs probably were. You can't look back and say "Well I should have done it that way" or "Well we have this awesome system, but the way it was presented in the first game didn't suit it well"I don't say this to be harsh, but to let you know those were both areas of your responsibility during game production, and to say it didn't work or wasn't presently appropriately falls on you. It is easy to say how you would change past design decisions or player encounters at the end of the day, for obvious reasons. Perhaps a wiser approach towards future projects would be to set clear, concise goals on how to approach past issues while being mindful of what worked well.

Pacing of these interactions and the overall plot are not bad at all, and when combined with the setting deliver a game you can jump into and feel hooked. I personally enjoyed the voiceacting and sound design.Alright-Play length and amount of content to experience on a single playthrough leaves something to be desired, don't blow your horn about a trilogy if they're all going to be this quick and rely on multiple playthroughs to deliver full circle. Content is one thing, double handling gets old after awhile. I appreciate that we have many choices, but some of them lack follow through if you play certain types of characters. Sometimes there is no foothold for a player with too much intuition that will scour out of the way areas.Lore dumps-the lore contained in this game is handcrafted and certainly interesting. The only problem outside of limited audio broadcasts/conversations is that if you want to experience any of it-have fun reading codex lore dumps in the menu. No offense but it was more fun to fly by the seat of my pants than do that and try to figure anything out, which seems to be a huge waste. Why gate so much great stuff behind one of the dullest interactions in your game?Plain bad-Shooting, Inventory management, sense of progression, jaggy shadowsThis is a game worth playing but it feels at times if it is grasping for too many things to have that "feature list" that tends to accompany recent steam releases. The shooting is just plain bad(especially if you want to play non-killing), the hud sucks for it. If you want to play a decent shooter don't come into Consortium expecting even that. To make the matter worse any inventory management feels like it is there just to be there. Most of the items I encountered had no practical use inside the story, and anytime I did use a weapon/ammo/armor it was unintuitive, a huge hassle, and most of all not even fun. These two areas need some polish or even to be redone completely if you want to really tout them as cornerstones of the gameplay experience. Which leads to my next point-progression. At the end of the day I felt like I made a difference, and was a set piece for some cool stuff. Even though I kept being swept along to the next issue there were a few "AHA" experiences in the plot or character interactions which left me wanting more. But you still feel very gated off from what is really happening, with few avenues to approach it in an otherwise very thoughtful and ambitious setup. Also the shadow jaggies are downright terrible, expect them to be a bit jarring even if you have a nicer PC. My final comments will be aimed at the developer review-you need to decide on what you want and get it right the first time, and budget the appropriate timelines and resources to it. There is a vocal audience that bought into this game when it released, and you can tell they felt let down by the compromises and changes you made to the content and schedule. I can believe how buggy the initial playthroughs probably were. You can't look back and say "Well I should have done it that way" or "Well we have this awesome system, but the way it was presented in the first game didn't suit it well"I don't say this to be harsh, but to let you know those were both areas of your responsibility during game production, and to say it didn't work or wasn't presently appropriately falls on you. It is easy to say how you would change past design decisions or player encounters at the end of the day, for obvious reasons. Perhaps a wiser approach towards future projects would be to set clear, concise goals on how to approach past issues while being mindful of what worked well.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												This review will be split into two parts as not everyone will want to look at the huge wall of text i have written.The long versionThis game is quite honestly one of the best RPG' s i have played in years. To be quite honest no game has resonated with me story wise as much as this game has. The story was brilliantly written, and quite honestly this is one of the best games i have played in years, and is one of the few games i have completed more than once. The characters are quite interesting, the story is brilliantly written, and you can tell the amount of effort they have put into this game is extremely large. While the combat is the worst part of this game by far, the game isnt there for the combat, it is there to tell a wonderful, interesting story. I loathed every time i had to shoot people, as i would much rather talk through all of the conflicts in the game. This indie game blows most AAA stories out of the water, and i dont think any game could come close to the quality of this games story. I have to reccomend this game to absolutley everyone who isnt a "HURR HURR SHOOT THE DUDES HURR HURR." sort of person, if you are looking for incredible combat look elsewhere. The other negative thing i found is that it is quite short, though it does reward reloading often, and even multiple playthroughs.The short versionThe positivesWonderful story that trumps most AAA gamesGreat CharactersIncredible amounts of effort put into itThe NegativesTerrible combatSomewhat short

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												I was pleasantly surprised at how encompassing the world is. The backstory is super fleshed out and very captivating. It's like a sci-fi 'choose-your-own-adventure novel' video game, with guns, and a murder mystery. Definitely unlike anything I've ever played before, and I mean that in the best way possible.The art style is different. It's almost cartooney-looking and the shadows look really bad. Which I wouldn't mind but although the textures and all around graphical quality is sub-par, the game is very gpu intensive at random points in-game. I'm playing with a r9 380 at 1080 and some instances such as a terminal displaying a hologram would drop my frame rate from 60+ to -30 fps.The actual shooting mechanics aren't great, but they aren't a huge part of the game. Consortium is definitely a story-driven adventure game with fps elements. In my story, I only experienced combat twice outside the training sequences.The story is pretty short in lenth, but rich with substance and a high replayability value. All-around, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and I'm eager to continue the adventure.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
 CONSORTIUM: A very Interesting "game" For starters, the game  does not  consider what it does as a "game", simply more of a mix between time travel and the matrix. The game begins with the simple and not soul crushing experience of  "THIS IS NOT A GAME, THESE ARE REAL PEOPLE AND REAL LIVES" (Really gets ya hyped up doesnt it?) and puts you into the "game" (You'll be seeing me use the term "game" throughout the review, simply because the game does not consider itself as a game, more simply "an experience")VISUALSSolid, runs off the source engine yet even through its source I get a somewhat decent framerate (averaging about 20 or so in a crowded section of the map) which is odd. Sure the game is new but in slightly older games (say, Portal 2 for an example, solely because it too is a source engine game) I got a wonderful amount of framerate (Averaging a 32 to 60 on my "crap-top") but graphics seem to be a major issue to me. even on the lowest setting and at a ridiculously low resolution the game still runs poorly, Definently would not recommend for older PCs.GAMEPLAYLike almost all source engine games, the gameplay was solid. I had fun and generally was interested in the plot (Which i will not spoil because reasons and even i'm not done with it at the time I wrote this review). I rarely encountered a game breaking bug or glitch ( the worst being when an NPC didn't spawn in the VR training section) It was fun but still challenging to an extent. The story(Though i like it cause y'know, i'm a major nerd for all thing futuristic) seems somewhat bland at first. Imagine the largest, Most chaotic and futuristic game of clue you can think of. Got it? Now add in EMPs, Rockets, US F-16s, an angry slavic man and then throw it all up at about the cruising altitide of a Boeing 747.Because that is essentially CONSORTIUM. VALUEIs it worth the $10 that Interdimensional Games is asking for?Sadly no, I (like many others) had picked up the "game" for free as part of the steam winter sale when this "game" came out. An asking price for a story that (Though very long) is rather mediocre shouldn't really be this high (though i should point out that the replay value of this game is totally amazeballs[thats right, amazeballs]) I would have been happy to pay the $10 in truth though, because c'mon guys. There is so much worse you could get for more than $10(Garfeild Karts anyone?)FINAL VERDICTI'd give it a 7/1110, The game is Solid in terms of gameplay and originality but is lacking in storytelling and plotOverall, CONSORTIUM is a truely great game. The mechanics used in the game are (as stated by the game) truely ground breaking. When i played it it felt like every choice I made had a reaction, had a consequence and I even felt regret for one.Pick up the game some time if you like Action RPGs and want to try something new

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
General ImpressionsCONSORTIUM is a short but great story-driven game for $9.99. It was a game that lay in cobwebs in my Steam Library for some time even after I was able to retrieve it during its free weekend. Having tried it though, I think it's safe to say that the game hooks you in and doesn't give you much chance to get out of immersion unless you're going for that route. Gameplay-wise, you can't really expect much in regards to the gun mechanics. Not that you should, that does not seem to be its main purpose in the game. The main purpose is really sort of exploring this alterntive universe, I do not consider myself to be a particularly heavily story-driven person, but having said that, you're not ramshackled to a ball and chain to the story. If you want to breeze through it as quickly as possible, you can. If you want to know this story better than anyone else, IDGI doesn't stop you.My Main gripe over the game ended up being the level layout and its room naming. I think it would be safe to say that I probably should have put more attention into looking at the map on the second floor, but with timed events, save-scumming is the only way to progress.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												I adore this game. It's difficult to find much wrong with it now that they've meticulously patched it, fixing all the performance issues and irritating bugs. This is possibly the first game I've played where the characters seem like real people with real relationships that really matter. You feel as though you're really leaving an impression on them as you attempt to solve the myriad mysteries of Zenlil, the futuristic plane, while a conspiracy of powers you can't hope to understand weaves its web below the surface. I'm even a big fan of the graphic style, which brings back nostalgic memories of 90s CG television shows like Reboot. Who knew flat-shaded textures could have such a charm to them?While it wraps itself in the guise of a first-person-shooter, Consortium is a conversational game first and foremost, with almost every encounter with danger solvable without needing to resort to circle-strafing and machine-gunning. As such it can be a more sedate experience than you're comfortable with if you're looking for a more conventional FPS. I'd very much recommend it to people who are more inclined towards adventure games and other more story-based genres.With how open-ended the game is and how many ways you can alter and affect the timeline, I reckon I'll be giving Consortium a bunch more playthroughs before the next installment.A+ - Very Recommended.

												EDITED BELOWI am quite upset with this game. I helped with testing the game and giving feedback to the developers hoping to improve the game to a playiable state, and they have done significant patches which have helped allot. Issues:- Allot of crashes related to the User Interface (moving items in and around your inventory) making the game unplayiable untill this issue is resolved- Clipping issues- And more crashesPros:- Excellent voice acting and setting, I cannot believe the amount of options and intereaction between NPC's. It is truely amasing!- Great feel to the gameConclusion:This game is not ready for release. The Dev's are working hard to resolve the issues and are doing a great job. However the game is still broken. I'd only reccomend purchasing this game if you can handle allot of crashes or if you are going to try and help the Devs.My rating of the game in its current state:3/10My rating of the game ignoring the crashes:9/10EDIT: The bugs are fixed and this game is amazing! Very good job considering the amount of work the developers have put in. A solid 9/10

												A real surprise, funny, witty, you can spend hours playing whatever character/mood you want with numerous timed dialogs. The timing on the answers avoid those tedious conversation mini-maxing and you just play whatever you fancy and to hell with the consequences. Somehow, after a small session I'm already enjoying the story, the gameplay and the overall experience better that a Mass Effect or equivalent AAA titles. Bring back the souvenirs of the good time I had playing Space Quest or Days of the Tentacle.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Looking at screenshots, I didn't expect much from this game.I could not have been more wrong. Quite possibly one of the best games I've ever played.An interesting concept which seems a little silly at first, but after only a few minutes of actual play you'll be totally immersed in the whole idea behind it. Not to mention the rich and highly developed setting.The whole experience is very head first. There's little telling you were to go or who anyone is, or even any names. Freedom is given entirely to you to figure out everything about the whole experience, no annoying HUD popups telling you everything. I love it.If you like role playing, this game is for you. I struggle to think of many finer examples.If like me, you're looking at screenshots and thinking it looks a bit crap, trust me; Try it. The plasticy looking environments and people are perfectly suited to the entire lore of the game.I hope you enjoy as much as I am right now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Interactive media and motion picture had a baby.  CONSORTIUM is an outstanding example of how immersive storytelling can be accomplished, with decisions and impacts that really matter.  A quick example: forgetting to charge your energy reserves before meeting with your boss can determine whether or not a crew member dies....  Not because it's scripted that way, but because you have to run to need energy reserves in order to inject a wounded crew member with healing nanites.  And if you aren't prepared, they bleed out before you get back.There are numerous other instances that truly inspire that this game is indeed another universe, that the characters are living, coping, and otherwise dealing with the stress of being in a tense military situation.Sadly, the graphics do not live up to this - The game went for a slightly cartoony look instead of a realistic look.  That said, it works well with the chosen art style, and it isn't the visual art that makes the game.  It's the audio, the writing, and the humanoid interactions and reactions.The game is a little short for what I was hoping (was able to fully complete 1 variant of the story in 2 hours), but it has quite a bit of variation and replayability based on what you do and don't do.TL;DR - Highly recommended if you want a story-driven adventure game that doesn't rely on logic puzzles or item gimmicks.  Plus, its story is awesomely meta.

number of helpful: 11 of 24 people (46%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												It took me a little while to get past Consortium's fairly ugly, Reboot-esque graphics, but I'm glad I did, because it's a pretty interesting game. In some ways, the game feels like a tutorial level for a bigger game - the game teaches you how to manage your health and armor and use one of five weapons, with loading screen tutorial texts to match, but there's almost no actual combat in the game, amounting to a single optional firefight and some VR training missions. But it also uses this to have a somewhat interesting setting - the entire game takes place on an airship on the way to your next mission, and along the way you deal with a locked room murder mystery and unearth conspiracies. The gameplay is mostly dialogue-based with occasional bits of action, and the dialogue offers enough variety to highly encourage multiple playthroughs with the amount of choices you get and secrets to find. The dialogue is made interesting by the fact that rather than just breaking the fourth wall, Consortium doesn't really have a 4th wall to begin with, and the player is recognized in the game as a person using the game (described in-universe as a software that allows you to view the future through someone else's eyes) to control the main character in the future. This also ties into a pretty extensive ARG that leads up to the game for those who find themselves wanting more of the game's lore, and if you don't want to play the entire ARG there's a free DLC package that gives you all of the documents to clue you in, but it's a pretty substantial read, running several hundred pages of PDFs. The game can be enjoyed without ever acknowledging the ARG, however. Consortium is a game that feels like a smaller part of a bigger game while still holding its own as a standalone experience, and the next game, Consortium: The Tower, is currently in development and will presumably start off where this game ends. At the base price of $15 I'd consider Consortium to be a decent purchase, but at its current sale price of $1.50 I don't see any reason not to give it a try if you're into dialogue-based stories.
